Mo called at nine thirty-three. She had a talent for arriving in the minute in which I was most likely to make excuses to the day.

“Seb,” she said. She called me Seb even though she had named me Sebastian and most of the world, when it bothered, went with Seb or Bash or, once, Sable. “I need you to look at a tap.”

“I’m not your plumber.”

“No, you’re not, but he’s not my plumber either. He’s late. They’re all late. Is it in their training? Lesson three: you’ll never be on time again? I can hear the tap across the road. There’s a woman over there, I see her in the mornings with the dachshund. Honestly, if my tap is louder than the putter of a little dog, something is wrong.”

“Your tap is louder than the dog? That’s catastrophic.”

“That’s the word. Catastrophic. I’ll make you a sandwich. Beetroot and Stilton. I know, I know, the colour is alarming.”

“You always loved an alarming sandwich.”

“You’re one to talk, Mr. Marmalade Brioche. Don’t think I don’t see your little posts online.”

“They’re not little,” I said.

She laughed, quick and bright, a bell over the bridge. “Come at eleven? Or when your group ends. I don’t want to be a cliché mother. I don’t want them talking and saying, there, she is, the classic northern mother, fussing with her son.”

“You could never be a cliché.”

“Go write. Go write and then come sort my catastrophe.”

We rang off and I put on my scarf and the coat with missing buttons that made me look like a student. Marmalade angled her head to watch the door. “Don’t think about eating the dough,” I warned her. “It’s beneath you to be that kind of cliché.”

On the Metrolink the windows were scratched with messages from men who didn’t know how to leave a legacy any other way. Two schoolgirls drew diamonds on each other’s hands. A man with a captain’s beard dozed and missed three stops. The conductor at Dane Road made a joke about singing in the wind and only one person laughed, and I wanted to ask him if it mattered to him that it was only one person, and did he hold onto each laugh like a coin, and did it still count if someone laughed and then immediately turned to take it back with a glare. I kept my thoughts to myself and got off at the Waterside.

Rani was at a corner table with a notebook the size of a dinner tray. “You’re on time,” she said, as if my punctuality were an act of formal rebellion. “How’s the baking?”

“Better than the writing.”

“It always is. You should bake a poem. Mary Berry would say—”

“Please don’t say Mary Berry.”

“—that a poem needs to rise, darling, and the crumb must be—”

“Stop it.” I laughed. “It’s not even that show.”

“What show? I’m making these notes for me. I’m going to pitch a TV programme called Flour Power. Do you know how many repeats there are in the day? I could be a millionaire by Tuesday.”

I took a sip of the coffee she slid to me that was more moral support than caffeine. “I wrote six hundred words,” I said, lying up.

“Good.” She knew I was lying and gave me the lie as a gift. “Read it.”

My six hundred words were one hundred and eighty-eight words carefully spaced and made to look like they were more by way of generous line breaks. Rani listened. She touched the margin with her index finger as if she could push the sentences deeper into themselves. “There’s a bit,” she said, “where he kneels to tie his laces and he thinks about how the world looks from the ground. That. Keep that. You’re good when you’re literally looking at something. No offence, but when you get out of your head, you get into the good stuff.”

“I’m always in my head.”

“Maybe bake in your head. Use your head as an oven. What does it smell like, Seb’s head? Cloves and resentment?”

“Cloves and honey,” I said. “And a trace of washing powder.”

Our group arrived in a soft wave: Benji with his backpack full of zines; Claire with her front-of-house smile from the theatre she ran; a man called Richard who was building a poem out of the names of trains. We workshopped. We were kind and sometimes not kind in ways that taught us to be better at both. I felt the world narrow and then open and then narrow again, and in each shape there was a different version of me: baker, writer, son.

At noon I hugged Rani and told her about Mo’s tap.

“Beetroot and Stilton,” she said. “Take a picture. Put it in your book.”

“I’ll put your shoes in my book.”

“Everyone will think the character is confident.”

“And loud.”

“And right.”

On the towpath the fairy lights were illuminated now and useless in daylight. A toddler in a puffer coat kicked a frozen leaf as if it were an enemy. At Mo’s house the front step had one of those mats that demanded you wipe your paws. She opened the door wearing an apron printed with lemons, her hair pinned up with two pencils as if she had been arrested by an urgent thought. She kissed my cheek and held my hand too long. It was her worst habit and my favourite.

“In,” she said, “in, before we lose all the heat in this house and the bill comes through the letterbox and laughs.”

“You were always good at personifying utility companies.”

“Yes, well. They deserve it.” She led me to the kitchen where the tap did, indeed, hiss. “See? The plumber says one. He says one. He said he’s on the way. I told him I would be at his house at midnight if he didn’t come.”

“You didn’t.”

“I might.”

I crouched under the sink. The cupboard smelled of old wood and something like dill. I had no real plans for fixing anything. I opened my mouth to say, I’ll call, I’ll be polite, he’s probably on his way, when the doorbell rang. Mo flapped her hand at me.

“That’ll be him,” she said, and then, “or a politician. Either way I’m going to make him tea and ask him if his mother’s proud.”

The plumber was ten years younger than me and looked as if he’d replaced a tap in the womb. He bounded in and said hello to my mother as if he’d known her since the bin men were respected. He bent under the sink, made the noises of someone who had seen a future written in copper pipe, and then assured us it was fixable. He had a name that might have also been the name of a soap opera character with a secret. Dean.

“Dean,” my mother said, as if testing whether it contained any extra vowels. “Would you like a biscuit?”

“I’m good,” he said, in the way that meant he would be better with a biscuit but thought saying so would be too forward.

“Sebastian,” she said, “make Dean two cups of tea.”

“Dean,” I said, “do you take sugar?”

“Nah,” he said. “I’m sweet enough.”

Mo laughed. She always loved a self-mythologist. I made the tea. I thought of the oven at home with its gentle heat and of Marmalade fairy-stepping across the window ledge and knocking a bag of rye flour onto the floor. The day had become a place I wanted to be—Mo at my shoulder, Dean talking in a dialect of numbers and measures. I could write this. I never wrote the worst things and I never wrote them in the present tense. Not then. Not yet.

When Dean left, the kitchen was quiet and the tap was chastened. Mo made the promised sandwiches. There are two ways to cut a sandwich and she always did both. She laid the triangles and rectangles on a plate with the pride of an artist who had spent a restless night stitching a problem into a solution. The beetroot bled onto the bread. The Stilton glowered. We ate in silence for the first few mouthfuls, because her sandwiches demanded reverence.

“Seb,” she said. “Are you going to enter that baking thing?”

“What baking thing?”

“The one from the magazine. Your Auntie Kath gave me the leaflet. She said, tell Seb. It’s amateur, so you’re allowed to be a semi-professional in your heart.”

“I’m already too professional in my heart. It would be an unfair advantage.”

“Don’t be daft. You make nice things and you put them on the internet and people click little hearts. You should have bigger hearts. And finally make some money. God knows your writing makes you a lot of satisfaction in the night and a lot of rent from me.”

“I pay rent.”

“Do you heck. You slip fifty quid into my coat pocket at Christmas and call me a landlord. I’m not complaining.”

“I’m doing okay, Mo.”

“I know you are. I know. But why not this? Baking is not cheating on writing. You think it is. It isn’t. Remember when you were little and you had that inflatable dinosaur—”

“Terry.”

“—Terry, the carnivore. You used to put him in the bath and then run into the kitchen to get a spoon and pretend you were feeding him pudding. He was an inflatable. He was full of air. But you fed him and you said, this is how he will grow. You always had more than one thing in your arms.”

“I wasn’t an organised child.”

“You were exactly yourself. Enter it. I want to be on television with an inappropriate sign. The northern mother. The cliché. I will write, I gave him the whisk.”

I laughed, but the thought lodged in the place where all my ill-advised ideas multiplied. “I’ll think about it,” I said.

“No. Do it. Think later.”

We talked about other things. The old neighbour who had moved away because her son wanted her to be closer to his family and she did not want to be closer to anyone; the woman at the butcher who had started offering paprika with every order like a wizard’s trick; my cousin’s new baby who had a head like a potato, in the best possible way. I left with leftovers and with a scarf Mo insisted I bring because “you always underestimate the cold, as if you have a contract with the wind.”

At home Marmalade had not eaten the dough but had slept on the bag of flour until her fur was dusted white. She looked at me as if she were a ghost risen from meal. I brushed her and the air was a little snowstorm. The oven had gone to sleep and needed waking with a firm hand. I baked the knots I’d tied earlier. The house filled with a smell that made thinking about fiction difficult. Then, at the table, with flour on my fingers, I opened my laptop and my email chimed.

And there it was: a subject line that looked like a dare.

We’re pleased to invite you to the final.

For a second I thought it was spam, the kind that wants you to believe you’ve won the lottery in a nation that uses different commas. Then I saw the logo of the magazine. Hearth & Home. Rani had mocked it as a magazine that imagined all emergencies could be solved by a well-folded throw. They ran a competition every year, the Great Northern Bake Off albeit without the rights, with a regional tour and a final filmed live for a video stream that people watched from sofas and phones as if they were catching up with a friend. I had sent in a photograph of my cardamom swirls and a recipe for my salted honey cake. I had done it after two glasses of wine and a nudge from a memory of Mo’s hands on my shoulders. I had sent it and then tucked the act away in the secret drawer where I kept things I wanted to happen without the embarrassment of wanting.

I clicked.

Dear Sebastian, 

We’re delighted to invite you to take part in the final of the Hearth & Home Amateur Baking Challenge. Your submission was a joy to read, and our judges were impressed by the originality of your flavours and the clarity of your method. The final will be held at the Glassworks in Castlefield on the 12th. We’ll be in touch with technical details (COVID compliance etc.) and a list of ingredients we’ll provide. We’d love you to prepare a showstopper on the theme of “Northern Routes.” 

Please confirm your availability as soon as possible. 

All best, 

Shivani
Hearth & Home Events

I read it twice and then a third time in which none of the words seemed to be language, just shapes spinning. The Glassworks. Castlefield. The word final hugged the page and glowed. I laughed, a sound like someone unwrapping foil slowly in a church. I stood and then sat immediately as my knees made an official complaint. “Marmalade,” I said. “We may be about to experience a brush with the minor leagues.”

She blinked. A greenish blink, serpentine. I forwarded the email to Rani with no body and then had to send a second one with a body because what if she thought I’d been hacked by a baker whose first act of malice would be to send invitations to strangers. My phone rang. Rani doesn’t believe in text messages for certain categories of excitement.

“This is a story,” she said. “This is a story with a predictable arc and yet I am thrilled. I’ll be in the audience shouting when everyone else is being politely northern. I’ll bring a sign that says SEB RISES.”

“I haven’t said yes yet.”

“Say it. Say yes. Say yes on the phone to me. I will pretend to be the events manager if you need a rehearsal.”

“Yes,” I said, and the word left my mouth and became a currency I could spend on other yeses. I typed the reply: I would be delighted to accept.

I called Mo.

“Hearth & Home,” I said.

“What about it?”

“I’m in the final.”

There was a small noise. Not shock—relief, I think, a distant bell confirming the hour. “You are,” she said. “Course you are.”

“You are not allowed to heckle the judges.”

“I won’t. I’ll just whisper loudly. Oh, my heart.”

“Are you okay?”

“Of course,” she said. “I’m not ninety. I’ll just be a little bit proud in the privacy of my stern face. I’ll get a new coat.”

“A coat?”

“If I’m going to be on the stream, they can’t see me in this old thing where the zip has ideas about my personality. Oh. Northern Routes. What does that mean? Trains? Pie?”

“It means never say pie to anyone from Wigan unless you mean pie.”

“Your father,” she began, and stopped, then said, carefully, “would have been delighted.”

We didn’t say his name much. Not because it hurt—pain becomes furniture—but because the room took on a shape when we did, and we were tired of rearranging ourselves. He had been someone who believed in work and in tools and in the idea of a day fulfilled. He’d died ten years ago on a day that had looked like any day, and on bad nights I still heard the rattle of tea mugs he’d put out that morning, as if there was a thin place between then and now and it could be crossed if only you knew the tune.

“I’ll make him a pie,” I said, which was what we said when we wanted to put something back and couldn’t.

“You’ll make him a pie,” she said, and then, brisk again, “Right. Now. Do you need me to taste? I can do it. I’ll do it for England. I’ll do it for Greater Manchester. I’ll do it for our street.”

“I’ll bring a prototype tomorrow.”

“Make two. We’ll need a control.”

I hung up and pink light came through the window, a flare on the canal, the fairy lights less ridiculous now that the day frayed. I felt the strange elasticity of time when it doubles back and lets you begin again right where you are. I opened my cupboards and took stock. Flour enough to feed a parade. Sugar like quiet snow. Butter. Candied peel I’d been saving for a reason that had only ever been imaginary. I opened the spice jar and the cardamom hit me with its green hush. Northern Routes. Routes, not roots. Journeys, maps, tracks. The Bridgewater Canal. The trams that slid along like careful knives. The motorway that carried us to the sea and back with chips. The recipes that had travelled in pockets and in handbags. Saffron from a market in Bury that made my fingers gold for days. FRANKS written in fading paint on a sign for a butcher who had outlived three economies. I chose a notebook page and wrote: seed cake studded with caraway and black tea soaked fruit. And beneath it: parkin reinvented, with rye and a seam of quince. And then: a braid that looks like the canal.

I began to bake the way some people begin to pray—not loud, not showy, but with a straightening of the back. I’d thought being invited into anything would make me arrogant. It made me careful. I measured and then measured again. I thought of my body carrying a recipe that belonged to people I had known and to people I had never met. I loved, suddenly, with a childish purity, the idea that I would be judged by women in cardigans and men in jumpers who had taught themselves how to make puff pastry by watching television on a low volume so as not to wake their children.

At nine I sat down with a wedge of test parkin that was still, frankly, a bit raw in the middle. I liked it anyway. Through the wall I heard my neighbour singing along to a song that had been famous when we were young and has never been forgiven for its optimism. I opened my laptop with sticky fingers and wrote five hundred words, real words this time, words that made my narrator reach for a handrail and miss and laugh. I thought of tomorrow, of a market for quince I did not need, of Rani’s sign. I went to bed with the smell of ginger in my hair and the rhythm of a recipe in my heart.

In the night I dreamed of the Glassworks, which I had never visited. I stood in a huge room with iron beams and a floor that remembered the weight of a hundred years. The judges were two women called Elsie and Mei-Lin and a man with a moustache so precise it could have been measured by a compass. My oven was a small mouth in a large wall. Mo was in the front row with a thermos. When I looked down I was wearing my father’s overalls, and they fit, and I took that as a kind of blessing you only get once in a life. Someone shouted, “Time,” and I put down my whisk and woke, the word ringing, neither threat nor promise, just the fact of the hour.

Morning came again, and I did what I always do: I made tea. I fed Marmalade. I read the email one more time to be sure I had not stitched the whole thing together from sleep. Then I went for a walk by the canal. The toe of my boot hit a stone and I nearly went in and laughed in the face of the water as if the water were a person who had told me a rude joke. A man with a hat like a collapsed cake nodded. I nodded back. My phone buzzed in my pocket and I thought of turning it off, and I knew already that this would be the shape of the coming days—baking, writing, answering people, telling the truth more often than not.

No one warned me that the first yes would require a thousand tiny yeses. But then again, no one warned me that I would come to love the next half hour as if it were an object I could hold.

When I got home, there was a package on my step. Inside: a whisk. An extravagant one. A note that read, in Mo’s handwriting, Because I’ll want my old one back. Don’t argue with your mother. I laughed and sent her a photograph of the whisk held aloft, as if I had pulled it from a stone. She sent back a sticker of a crown. Rani texted to say I should practice under pressure and offered to ring my doorbell at random shouting, “You have thirty seconds!”

I stood at the kitchen table with my notebook open and my hands empty and thought, all right then, all right, come on, let’s do this. The kettle popped and hissed. Someone outside started a car that did not want to be started. A child on a scooter shrieked with joy and then, abruptly, sorrow. The day arranged itself at the window like a show I was ready to watch and to interrupt and to make, somehow, my own.

I did not start with the braid. I started with a list and then argued with it like a man on a bus who has just been told the timetable is a suggestion. The list wanted to be sensible. It wanted sturdy nouns, quantities with decimals, methods that would comfort a judge into thinking I had already passed. But I found myself writing things like a seam of quince as if I were planning surgery and then underlining rye until the R looked like a canal loop. Northern Routes did not want me to be tidy. It wanted me to admit that a map is a story and so is a recipe. I tore the page out and stuck it to the cupboard where Marmalade could not skate across it. I made tea as if I could boil the problem into steam.

Rani texted a photograph of a sheet of cardboard painted with fat letters. SEB RISES had evolved into SEB RISES OR WE RIOT and then had softened again under her brush to SEB RISES (NO PRESSURE). She had ringed the O in pressure with tiny flames as if the letter were a hob. I told her she was deranged and she sent back a gif of a woman dusting flour over a chandelier. In the group chat Benji suggested I incorporate "found materials," by which he meant little square poems cut into the crust, and Claire said that would get me disqualified, and Richard replied with a line of train names that read like a psalm. I put my phone face down and took out a bowl that had belonged to Mo's mother and had a chip the shape of an ear. It made a sound when you tapped it that was neither full nor empty, and my grandmother had always said that was the point of good crockery, to teach you there is something between.

I began with parkin because it felt like an exam in respect. I scalded the oatmeal and smelled the moment the treacle decided to stop being sullen and yield. Ginger went in and a measure of black pepper so tiny I pretended it was an accident even though I wanted the heat. I had quince in a bowl that the woman at the market had sold me with an apology for their bruises and a compliment for my scarf as if one cancelled out the other. I could have driven to the supermarket, but Mo had said Bury, and when Mo tells you to go somewhere, some part of you ties your laces and goes as if she is the weather. The day after the email I had walked through that market and brushed shoulders with men who had bought the same brand of socks for thirty years, and I had let my hands hover over a heap of saffron so bright it might have been illegal. The spice merchant had said the word Iran softly as if the syllables were glass and I had promised to treat the threads like royalty. I bought tea in a packet with a boat on the front and caraway seeds that got into the seams of my pocket and turned up in my change.

I stewed the quince with a sliver of lemon and a tablespoon of the tea and watched the pieces soften as if the fruit had decided to be generous. The plan was to line the parkin with a thin band of quince as if it were a road cutting through moorland. I would peel the paper and the cake would show a seam like a history book, and the judges would nod at my restraint and I would pretend not to mind that it was parkin and parkin does not perform. It is a cake that keeps its counsel and improves in the dark, and it is hard to romance a judge with the promise that something will be better in three days when the whole event is calibrated to the minute. I took it out and pressed a finger to the top and it hummed and sank and rose. Marmalade leaped onto a chair and gave me the look she reserves for times when I am unfaithful to her brand of attention.

At noon Mo arrived with the air of someone who had remembered that she left the iron on and then remembered that she no longer owns an iron. She hung her new coat on the back of a chair with a flourish and moved straight to the kettle with the instinct of a woman who had not walked into a kitchen without making a drink since she was nineteen. The coat was green and had a hood that could have sheltered a family. She had pinned an enamel badge to the pocket with a tiny drawing of a tram. She held up the whisk in both hands as if she expected me to feign astonishment and then pretended to be offended when I didn't pretend. We arranged slices of experimental parkin on a plate and she said nothing for two bites and then said, in full, "It's moody," and I felt absurdly proud of a square of sugar being accused of having a temperament.

"Moody is not a category on the judging sheet," I said, even though I hadn't seen a judging sheet and doubted such a thing existed outside my anxiety.

"It should be," she said. "It's very northern to respect a food that can't be rushed and has a face like it's about to tell you a cautionary tale. This is good. It's maybe a touch wet. Do you want me to be tactful or useful?"

"Useful, always."

"Then your quince seam is fat. Your ginger is handsome. Your top is dark in a way that makes me fancy it with butter and yet I know that would be blasphemy. And if you bring me a cup of tea I won't have to say anything about the fact that your oven runs hotter on the left."

Rani would have called Mo a national resource and then tried to recruit her. I made the tea and she turned the mug in her hands as if it were a little planet. We planned. The parkin would be made two days in advance and sealed as if it had secrets. The showstopper would be a braid because I could not resist a chance to tie stories into knots. I took out the saffron and let the filaments fall into warm milk and watched the liquid change its mind about the colour of itself. Rye and white flour together, cardamom and honey, a little orange zest like a borrowed sunshine. I drew an oval and turned it into a map with my pen. Three plaits for the canal and the ship canal and the river. Seeds pressed into the braids to mark the locks. A glaze of black tea and sugar to give a lacquer that would read as rain. On the side, little rolls shaped like milestones, filled with quince and caraway like you might find a handful of secrets in a pocket.

Mo did not say, it's too much, which is the sentence I am both afraid of and grateful for when someone loves me. She said, "One thing at a time," and then she said, "Don't overcomplicate what you can make beautiful with your hands."

I practised without the mixer because Shivani wrote back with a list that read like a teacher's email in a year that had turned schooling inside out. They would have stand mixers but there might be electrical issues and the brief had a line about robustness. The ovens were calibrated but we were warned that one corner of the room had a draught. We would have ninety minutes alone on our showstopper after the technical challenge that we would not know until the morning. Could we bring our own spices, labelled; our own tins, as long as we didn't use them to hide a second cake; our own aprons, as long as the apron did not advertise anything except our worst habits. There would be hand gel and the cameras would be discreet in the way that anything can be discreet when it has a red light. We were to arrive with proof of a test taken at a time that made sense, and if we felt unwell we were to tell someone and be loved from a distance.

I stood at the table and kneaded and told myself stories about the men and women who had kneaded before me and I let my shoulders burn until sweat ran down my spine. My father had tied ropes and loops without looking, had made a lark's head out of nothing, had once made me a little ladder out of string and explained that sometimes the ladder has to be there before you know you need it. I braided and unbraided and Muldoon from next door knocked because somehow dough has a knock, a polite thud that tells old men that young men might be doing something worth interrupting. He is not called Muldoon. His name is Mr. Halley, and he is a widow who wears a hat no matter the weather and says things like "the nineteen eighty-six winter was a proper winter," but when I moved in Mo called him Muldoon for an afternoon and he has been Muldoon ever since.

"Smells like commitment," he said, standing on the threshold and peering around as if he might catch out my cleanliness in a lie.

"It smells like needing to practise."

"Same thing," he said. "I used to teach lads to sit their hands. You have to learn to look at something without touching it. You look and you wait and then you know."

"What did you teach them to operate?"

"Engines," he said, and then, "trams. I had one boy who minded the brakes like a mother and one boy who liked to see how fast the handle would spin. You'll forgive me for thinking you are the brakes."

"I'll accept that," I said, because more often than not I am the brakes. "Do you want to taste parkin?"

"Does the Pope have a hat," he said, and then proceeded to tell me, as if I had asked, about a driver who had taken a corner too fast and had been forgiven by a city that likes to pretend it is made of right angles. He tapped the parkin with one finger and nodded and said, "Don't cut the seam too wide," and then insisted that I take a painting from his hall that had belonged to his wife. It was a watercolour of the aqueduct at Barton and you could tell which way the wind was going by the way the painter had chosen to leave the paper white. I said no twice and yes once and he left with a wave that could have been a blessing or a stretch.

At the library the next day Rani staged what she called a "controlled panic." She had borrowed the kitchen at the community centre by pretending she was going to host a workshop about soup, and then she had set a timer and told me I had to bake the braid from start to finish with only what I could carry in a bag. She banged on the door at intervals and shouted instructions like a benign general. Claire and Benji and Richard sat at a long table and pretended to be judges, which meant they alternated between saying things like, "You've got twenty minutes, can we see a finish?" and taking photographs for social media with their tongues in their cheeks. My dough rose with all the magnetism of a brick. The draught did not help. My hands, which at home had become orchestras, became forks. When the timer went and Rani did an air horn noise that echoed off the tiles, my braid was the right shape but the wrong spirit and I felt tears press my eyes in a way that reminded me of being twelve and accidentally kicking a ball into a conservatory.

Rani turned the oven off and turned me round by my shoulders and said, "Look at me. We do not cry about dough in a room with a folding table. We cry about dead pets and lost loves and the time we left our book on the bus and never saw the end. We do not cry about a practice. Say it. This is a practice."

"This is a practice," I said, and the phrase was both a spell and a scolding.

Claire cut into the braid and made appreciative noises like a woman who had wanted to say something far worse but had decided to let me be fragile. Richard suggested I reduce the honey by a nerve and increase the caraway, because he liked a bake that talked to him as it went down, and Benji said, "It looks like an actual map," in a tone that made me believe there was at least one person in the world who would eat bread because it was shaped like a city. We made a list of adjustments and Rani offered me a napkin and then refused to give it to me until I said "I am magnificent even when I'm under-proved," which I said with minimal sarcasm. We cleaned the counters because the woman who had lent Rani the key had asked her to treat the place "as if the Queen was popping in for a bowl of stew," and even though there was no queen and no stew, we did what we were told.

On the evening news the storm had a name. I have never trusted storms with names because they feel like guests at a party who will arrive with a bottle of something and then announce they are moving in. The presenter stood in front of a map that had been sketched by an optimist and sounded like a man who had prepared for crisis by filling his freezer. I turned the volume down and wrote until my head felt like it had been worn smooth by a tide. In the book my protagonist finally touched the lemon tree and found it hot to the skin even in winter, and that seemed like a pretty flagrant metaphor and I let it stand because sometimes you need to be obvious to yourself.

Late, the lights flickered and then went out, and the flat shifted into the kind of dark that makes you aware of the bones of your face. Marmalade, who had previously been certain the storm was beneath her, sat up and decided to confess that she was a mammal. I found candles with the air of a man rewarded for his hoarding and lit them and watched the walls become adolescent again. The dough in the bowl, midway up, sighed as if the storm had knocked on the door and told it a rude joke. I covered it with a damp tea towel and a folded jumper and improvised a proving drawer next to the radiator that had the decency to keep working. I sent Mo a message to tell her not to walk out in the dark to look at the fairy lights on the bridge and she replied with a string of emojis that looked like a small orchestra. Halley, through the wall, sang two verses of The Leaving of Liverpool and then stopped, which was more disconcerting than if he had carried on.

In the morning the storm had shoved our town into a shape we recognised and resented. Bins were in the positions bins take when they have rehearsal for a revolution. The man with the fairy lights had lost three and tied two more in a knot that I could not untangle even with my eyes. The canal was fat with attitude. I wanted to stay inside and make the kitchen a church, but Shivani had arranged a pre-final call for all the competitors, and I had decided to be the kind of person who showed up for his own life. We joined a grid of faces, nine of us, and all of us arranged our expressions into that awkward friendliness you see at a party where someone promised you there would be snacks and then lied. There was a woman in a purple cardigan with a plate of jam tarts on a chair behind her, and a man in a vest I could not forgive who told us he was a beekeeper three times. There were two young men who shared a screen and elbowed each other like brothers or lovers and laughed whenever anyone said the word "laminate," and a woman about my age with an apron printed with hot air balloons and a care in her face that made me want to be on her team.

"Welcome," Shivani said, as if she had just arrived in our houses with a basket. She talked us through the timings and the choreography and reassured us that the judges would not, in fact, be looking for blood. She told us there would be a camera that stayed with each of us quietly, and that if we felt it breathing, to tell it to mind its business. She told us that the theme meant what we made it mean, and that she had seen past winners be as literal as gravy and as fanciful as night. The purple cardigan woman asked if we could bring our own jam, and the beekeeping vest man asked if he could garnish his bake with edible flowers from his garden, and one of the elbowing men asked if it was okay to cry on camera, and Shivani said it was okay to be honest as long as we didn't swear. He typed a line of asterisks and everyone seemed to sigh with relief.

After the call, the kitchen felt new, as if it had been visited by a civic inspector and found in good order. I kneaded and braided and split the loaves into lengths so I could practise the oven shuffle. I set up a fan in the corner to fake the draught and I spoke out loud because I needed to hear my own timing. Ten minutes and rotate, five minutes and brush, fifteen minutes and check a bottom with my knuckle which I would inevitably describe later as knocking on a door. I made my hands remember where everything lived without looking. I hid the honey so I wouldn't drown the loaf in a bath of apologies. I made the quince seam narrow, a ribbon instead of a road, a line of gold where the knife would find it.

At some point in the afternoon I caught sight of myself in the kettle and saw my father, which was unfair of kettles and fathers both. I had his mouth when I concentrated and the way my jaw took a stand when it decided to be good. I stood with my back to the counter and ate a slice of the second attempt and tried to decide whether the parkin liked me. Bread is forgiving. It wants to be eaten. Parkin wants to be left alone until it forgives you for making it. I wrapped it in paper and slid it under a shelf as if I were tucking a child under a bed and told it a story about the time a baker had once sold out of buns in a little market and gone home and cried because he didn't know how to be as good as people needed him to be.

In the evening, Mo brought stew because she said storms are an excuse to be nineteenth-century, and we ate with our elbows on the table while Marmalade performed the long con of being a cat who likes gravy. We talked about my father and then moved him gently to the corner of the room where he always sits in our conversations, and then we let him watch us without insisting he say anything. We made a plan for the morning of the final that involved leaving too early, because Mo has a philosophy that begins and ends with being early enough to break something and fix it before anyone knows. She laid out my apron and shook her head at a stain that she said told the story of a pear cobbler and I said she was a forensic genius. She put the whisk in my bag and told me not to let Rani take it to use as a baton. She told me to sleep and to ignore any dreams involving collapsing ovens or moustaches shaped like question marks. She told me that whatever happened I had already given the world a good loaf and a moodily decent parkin and a day, and a day is not nothing.

I lay in bed and did not sleep. I listened to an old podcast about sourdough as if I were revising for a test in breathing. I composed the first lines of a scene in my novel in which a man who thinks he is made of winter realises he has been summer all along, and then I laughed at myself because sometimes my earnestness is the most northern thing about me. I counted the objects I would lay out on the table in the Glassworks as if they were lucky coins: the apron, the bowl, the jar of cardamom, the honey in its heavy glass, the packet of saffron, the tin with the secret paper lining for the parkin, the brush that had lived a previous life as my father's paintbrush and that I had cleaned so thoroughly you could only see its past if you were an archaeologist. I considered texting Rani to tell her to cancel her sign because it would be too loud next to my heart, and I did not because I wanted someone to shout when the world went shy.

Morning found me before the alarm as if it were afraid to lose me. I made tea and pretended to drink it with serenity and then remembered serenity is a theatre and I have never auditioned. I packed the bag and then unpacked it because I had not put the saffron in, and then repacked it and added a packet of raisins as if there might be a child at the venue who required a snack. I forgot my phone and went back for it. I petted Marmalade and told her she would be in charge of the perimeter while I was gone, and she turned her back in a way that made me feel both scolded and forgiven. The wind had given up and gone to bother another town. The canal was glassy and sulking. The fairy lights were still out, because it was morning. I locked the door and checked the handle twice because some days you have to make sure a boundary stays a boundary.

On the tram I recognised my own adrenalin in other people. There was a man in a suit pinching the bridge of his nose, a girl in a school blazer reading a book with her finger moving under the line, a woman in a tracksuit holding a bunch of keys like she might use them to conduct. I stood by the door and watched my reflection ripple and decided I was a person on his way to try his best. Sometimes a sentence like that is all you can bear, and sometimes it is everything. I texted Mo to tell her I had boarded and she replied with a photograph of a thermos and three mince pies arranged as if for inspection. I texted Rani to say if she brought the sign I would die and she replied that death is a small price to pay for solidarity. I watched the city open and close like a throat. I let the morning take me, and I thought about what it means to make something and then let it be seen.

Castlefield was bluer than I had expected. The sky had found a hole in itself and poured. The Glassworks, when I reached it, looked like a building that had been taught to be polite. It had steel ribs and old brick and a doorway that wanted to tell you not to be silly. Outside, Shivani stood with a clipboard and a scarf that made her look like a flag, and she raised her hand and my name came out of her mouth tidy and correct. Mo walked towards me with the stride she reserves for events in which she has to pretend she is not the mother, and she managed, for three seconds, to be demure before whispering in my ear that she had given Richard from the group directions to a car park that may or may not exist. Behind her, Rani lifted the sign and then lowered it and then lifted it again as if it were a bird she was coaxing into flight. I breathed in air that smelled of wet slate and coffee and the particular electricity of people who have chosen to be in a room where they might fail gloriously. I picked up my bag. I took a step toward the door and did not think of anything except dough.

Inside, the air had the charged neatness of a place that had been cleaned twice and then left to wait. The floor had a gloss that made even my boots stand to attention. Steel tables stood in two rows with enough space between them to prevent territorial wars, each one laid with a cutting board, a set of knives with their blades tucked under guards like sleeping fish, a stack of bowls in graduating sizes, and a laminated sheet with our names as if we were about to sit an exam. The ovens were built into a long wall and blinked an even red at us, a row of small, patient planets. Above them, a gangway ran the length of the room, and beyond a glass partition the audience seats stepped up in shallow tiers. Someone had thought very hard about how to make this old bone of a building feel like a church of competence.

Shivani ticked my name, clipped a green wristband around my arm and pointed me to my station with a smile that said she had already put out several small fires and would do it again without complaining. I found my bench near one end of the row, close enough to the corner to sense the seam in the air where warm met cold. If I leaned to the right, a draft trailed its hand along my shoulder, polite but insistent, like a friend reminding you that you have somewhere to be. I put my bag down and unpacked the things I was allowed to bring: the jar of cardamom, my small tin of saffron with its ridiculous felt lining, my own wooden spoon because sometimes you need a familiar handle, and the brush that had once painted a skirting board in our old house and now glazed bread with tea. A camera operator materialised at the edge of my vision, his lens blinking at chest height. He introduced himself as Ayo and explained he’d be with me all day, and that I should pretend he was a coat stand until he spoke and revealed he was a person. He had kind eyes above his mask and a habit of rocking back on his heels as if measuring the room for a door.

The other bakers assembled like the first day of a workplace where everyone had accidentally worn their personality on their clothes. Purple Cardigan had introduced herself on the call as Hester and in person she had a face that had practised every version of patience. She nodded at me and balanced a plate of jam tarts on the edge of her station because some people travel with their proof. The beekeeper in the vest was called Alfie and he wore the kind of smile that had got him through a hundred conversations about stings. He kissed the tips of his fingers and raised them to the ceiling when he saw the bank of ovens, and I liked him even though he used the word “nectar” like it owed him money. The two who elbowed each other were Saj and Luke and the way they said each other’s names had a decades-old bruise of affection in it. The woman with the balloon apron was Jas, shorter than she’d looked on the screen, with a neat halo of hair and a way of aligning her mise en place that made me want to hand her my life and say, tidy it. We did the British shuffle of smiles over our masks and half-waves and the unspoken contract to help if someone’s tray hit the floor.

Up on the gangway the audience took their places at a careful distance, a scatter of coats and knitted hats and eyes. Rani slid in next to Mo with the sign folded in half like a secret that was trying not to be a secret. Mo had her thermos and two mince pies in a napkin and the green hood of the new coat tucked under her chair like a well-behaved pet. She took a photograph of me and, because she is not cruel, did not shout my name across the room, but it was on her face anyway. I waved in the small way you wave when you have already decided this is too much attention and you will manage it by pretending to be an understated sort of person until your own heart believes you.

Shivani stepped forward and introduced the judges, and for a brief second it was like the dream had loaned me a detail. Elsie Dacre had the straight back of a woman who refused to apologise for flour and a cardigan the colour of boiled sweets. She ran a bakery in Rochdale that had survived the fashions of three decades by treating fashion like a draft and moving the cakes away from it. Mei-Lin Patel carried her sleeves pushed up as if at any second she might reach into sugar and draw out a swan; she had a patisserie in Ancoats that people queued for even in rain that felt like revenge. The moustache belonged to Crispin Holt, a food historian from a corner of the world where food had been studied more than it had been eaten, and his tweed was so persuasive that I believed he might produce a footnote if I shook him. They took their places behind a calm wooden bench, and Shivani, who could have coaxed a confession out of a stone, told us to face the ovens and breathe.

“For your technical,” Mei-Lin said, the word making my stomach tilt as if we had driven too fast over a small hill, “we’d like you to make twelve individual Manchester tarts. You’ll find a list of ingredients and a recipe with… guidance.” She let the pause sit there and smiled with her eyes. “Shortcrust pastry, raspberry jam, set custard, desiccated coconut on top. No banana.”

A ripple ran through the room that was half laughter and half grief. Hester made a small noise that might have been protest on behalf of the school canteen. Crispin leaned into his microphone like a man about to argue that the banana was a twentieth-century aberration and had no place in civilisation.

“Two hours,” Elsie said, which was the sort of mercy that carried a threat. “We’ll be looking for crisp pastry, no soggy bottoms, a custard that doesn’t sulk, and a top that says you know what you’re doing with coconut. Off you go.”

I have made custard a hundred times in my life and every time it behaves like a lover who needs reassurance. I read the recipe sheet, which gave us times as if time were a thing that belonged to everyone equally, then put it down and talked myself through a plan. Ditch the mixer; the pastry would be better by hand and faster if I trusted my fingers. Cold butter, rubbed in until it looked like it had forgotten once being a block. A light hand with the water, a rest that would have to be a gesture rather than a meditation. I weighed the flour, counted the breaths between cutting the fat and bringing the whole mess together, and tried not to think about the camera that might be turning my concentration into a story. Ayo stood back and hummed the smallest fragment of a tune, which would have annoyed me in any other kitchen and here made the world expand. We each had a drawer marked “fridge” that felt like a joke until it whirred into life and proved itself useful. I slid the dough in and pretended I couldn’t hear the draft whispering that I ought to be doing more.

Blind bake. The words would always sound counterintuitive to me, like “civil war” or “healthy char.” I rolled the dough thinner than my nerves wanted and pressed it into the tart tins sitting like patient coins on my tray. Prick, line, beans. The oven door bit at me with its heat and I thought of the cold air I’d left behind on the towpath and felt a small, ridiculous gratitude for the fact that we can make our own weather. The custard in the pan was milk and eggs and sugar and courage, and I stirred until the motion became the point and the whisk drew a figure of eight like a signature. No banana, I told myself like a mantra, no banana, and saw in the corner of my eye Alfie look as if he had been waiting his whole life to defy that instruction and then decide he did not want to be a martyr for fruit.

I turned, three turns, rotated the tins, knocked a knuckle against a case to hear a sound that would tell me what to do next. The draft moved across my cheek and I moved the bowl to a warmer spot and blinked hard because steam is sometimes a substitute for tears. When the beans came out, the cases looked as they ought, which is to say both mean and promising, and I brushed them with a wash of egg to seal the deal and slid them back in for the briefest of second acts. The jam was the sort of red that tells a child a story and I spread it thin because nobody wanted a tart that looked like it had gone to war. I poured custard and the wobble gave me a sermon about humility. Hester caught my eye and made a face that said her custard had decided to remain liquid as an act of principle, and I wanted, with an ache that surprised me, to tell her she was doing fine.

We stood, briefly, fifteen of us in a room advertised as an event, and watched something set that we could not hurry. Ayo leaned in and asked me to talk through what I had done as if I had done anything except not fall apart, and I said words about ratios and instincts and my father’s habit of tapping things and waiting, and Mei-Lin paused by my bench and did not say anything condemning, which was as much praise as I could cope with. The coconut snowed with a pleasing sort of greed. I lifted a tart and the custard held and the pastry stayed where it was supposed to be, brown at the edges like a sensible hedge. One of them sank, a small betrayal, and I moved it to the back of the tray, which is a ridiculous sacrifice because the judges are as familiar with that trick as they are with heat. I presented my twelve in two tidy rows like a man who knows he cannot hide his flaws and instead dares you to love them.

Judging the technical meant being watched while you tried not to want to be liked and failing. We stood to one side while the three of them moved down the line, knives cutting clean little domes of judgement, and I tried not to let my eyes latch on to anyone’s face for too long in case I borrowed their joy or their dread by mistake. When they reached mine, Crispin held one up to his nose and sniffed like a fox. Elsie tapped the base and nodded, just once, as if acknowledging that the earth did, indeed, rotate. Mei-Lin cut and lifted, the custard stayed conversational and she said, in a voice that could have been meant for me or for the tart, “Good set.” The jam was perhaps a mark too thin. The coconut was perhaps a whisper too enthusiastic. But there was no banana and we all relaxed as if a small cultural war had been avoided.

We lined up for the reveal of the technical rankings, numbers written on cards that had been slid under plates for the cameras to have their moment. The twins came first because their custard had the unflappable quality of men who have never been late to a bus, and Hester crept to third with a pastry that had a mother’s genius for crispness, and I landed in fifth, which in my heart translated to, you do not embarrass the room, and also, yes, you could have gone easier on the coconut. Alfie was seventh and took it with a grin that made it impossible to be cross, and Jas, who had been quiet all morning, looked at her fourth place as if it were a secret she intended to keep to herself.

Shivani gave us ten minutes to reset and in that time my hands learned how to be mine again. I wiped the bench and laid out the things that would anchor the next hour and a half: the flour in its bag folded over to keep it neat; the yeast in its small jar like the good idea it could be; the milk in a jug that I warmed with a glance at the corner of the room that had decided to be winter. I checked the saffron as if it were a small creature that might make a run for it. I brushed a speck of jam from the edge of my station because I had the sense, as I often did, that leaving the wrong red in the wrong place would hex the day. Ayo leaned in and told me my mum had cried a very specific kind of cry at the end of the technical that had set off a chain reaction in three strangers, and I nodded and did not look up.

“For your showstopper,” Elsie said when we were called back to attention, “we want something that makes sense of our theme. Northern Routes. Sweet or savoury. Tell us a story, and make it edible.”

It was like being given permission to be as sincere as I wanted. I tipped the flour into the bowl and added rye like a suggestion rather than a command. Milk warmed, saffron turned its flag, cardamom crushed under the flat of a knife and released that green-dark perfume that had become a part of my house. Honey went in and told me not to apologise with it later. The yeast woke and proved it by blooming like gossip. I mixed until the flour confessed and kneaded until the dough stopped complaining. Ninety minutes is an argument with time if you are asking it to be generous. I told myself to trust the muscle memory of my hands more than the part of my head that wanted to compose an essay. The draft tugged at my sleeves like a child and I moved the bowl under the edge of a heat lamp they’d provided for exactly this kind of day. I let my palms hold the bowl like a planet and added warmth with the old, unromantic method of being alive.

They came to visit as the dough rose. Judges are not there to comfort, but Elsie’s presence had the effect of someone putting a hand on your briefcase and telling you you’d packed enough. I explained the braid, the three strands for the canal, the ship canal and the river, the seeds pressed in for locks, the black tea glaze for rain, the quince seam that would run the length of one plait like a road you could walk by taste. Mei-Lin asked how I would keep the quince where it belonged, and I told her about reducing it to a paste and piping it in rather than spooning it and letting it wander like a pilgrim. Crispin stroked his moustache like a pet and said something about heavy symbolism, and I let myself smile because if there is a thing I will be accused of, let it be that I tried to say something and then said it again with seeds.

The braid is a simple shape and also the most complicated. The three ropes laid out and the way the wrist learns that over-under-over is less about pattern and more about kindness. I rolled, I flattened, I piped a thin gold line down the centre of one strand and pressed the edges up to meet and hold it as if I were tucking in a child who wriggles. I worked faster than my instincts liked and slower than the clock wanted. Saj and Luke had decided on shortbreads layered into a map you could eat with rectangles for stations and I loved them for it without being able to tell them so. Hester rolled out suet dough for a roly-poly that made sense of railway halts and was sewing in dark jam like a seamstress. Alfie had made a honeycomb ring and was threading marzipan bees along a sugar road, and I prayed that his bees would not be judged for their cheer. Jas laminated pastry like someone folding a letter they were going to send without opening again, and her bench had an order that asked me to stand up straighter.

The draught took a bite at the left edge of my bench and my braid, once shaped and laid, rose politely at the far end and then sulked at the near. I tilted the tray, which felt like performing a magic trick in front of an engineer, and then I swallowed my pride and asked Ayo to ask Shivani if I could move the proof to the other side for five minutes. He went to ask and came back with a shake of his head, and I had the odd surge of gratitude for rules, because sometimes you need something to push against. I inverted a metal bowl over the fragile end and trapped a pocket of warmth that sent the dough a note. When it had swollen in a way that made the slice of me that is a child feel relief, I slid it into the oven and shut the door and told myself not to look for five minutes. A person can learn to look without touching, and then to trust without staring, and then to know without needing to narrate every act. Five minutes came, then ten, and I turned and brushed with tea and sugar until the surface shone like wet tarmac.

Rani held the sign up once, briefly, the letters of my name like a thing made of rope. Mo was talking to a woman with a hat pinned at an angle that suggested she had dressed for television in the sense that a person dresses for leaving the house for the first time after an illness. I could see the way Mo’s mouth went when she was being fierce for someone else’s sake, and I had a sudden image of her explaining the difference between patience and passivity to a stranger who had just said her daughter ought to calm down. I thought of my father without deciding to, the way you think of the anchor of a boat when you feel the boat float, and I was grateful again for the soft vulgarity of yeast.

There was a moment, as there always is, when the braid looked like it would burn on the outside before its inner self was ready to be admired. I knocked the underside and listened for the sound that is not unlike laughter. I rotated and made a small adjustment that seemed like pretending to control weather, and a seam at the junction of two strands opened in a thin smile and let the quince show. I told myself not to panic because a seam is not a wound, and I pinched gently and brushed the place with tea to glue it to itself. I reached for the caraway and pressed seeds in along a straight run as if I could convince anyone that they had always belonged there. The little milestones—rolls wrapped around thumb and forefinger and filled with a smear of quince like a secret you tell a friend and not a crowd—went in for their short bake and came out browned as if they had been out in the weather and liked it.

Time was called by a person with a voice that knew how to land. We had thirty seconds by one count and a lifetime by another. I lifted the braid to the board I had brought that looked enough like a map to be embarrassing if the bread had not justified the theatre, and I laid the milestones along one side with gaps because I have always been suspicious of perfection. I wiped the smear of tea from the edge of the board and stepped back and only then noticed that I had not breathed properly for several minutes. Ayo made a little sound that might have been a yes or might have been a yawn and in either case felt like kindness. Saj whispered “nice” at a volume that would have gotten him in trouble in a library, and Hester patted her roly-poly like a cat. The room exhaled, which is always the moment when you remember the thing you forgot, and then remembered that this time you had not.

Judging the showstopper is pageantry and it is also the awkward intimacy of a stranger telling you who they think you are. They began at the far end and worked towards me, and I watched Crispin’s eyebrows and Elsie’s hands and the tilt of Mei-Lin’s head and tried to remind myself that today was not the sum of me. Alfie’s bees looked ridiculous and therefore perfect, and Elsie told him his honey had been heavy-handed in the dough and he took it like a man who knows the difference between love and flattery. Jas had made a series of small laminated parcels that opened to reveal spices and fruit that told the route of her grandmother’s kitchen to her own, and when she cut one the sound of the layers could have paid rent. They told her she had done a delicate thing without needing applause and she nodded like a person who saves her crying for later.

When they reached me the braid had set into itself and the glaze had caught the light like a street after rain, which was a luck I had asked for and been given. Elsie pressed the edge and approved of the colour without saying she approved of the colour, which is to say she didn’t frown. Crispin bent to read the caraway road as if it were a text and then raised his chin at me, and I spoke the sentence I had rehearsed in which I described the three strands, the locks, the glaze, the quince, the rye, and the way the canals had kept us together when the weather was ugly. He cut and the knife met a resistance that meant the crust had thought about me, and he lifted a slice and the seam of quince sat where I had asked it to sit. Mei-Lin took a piece and her eyes did a thing that I couldn’t translate and I realised that sometimes you don’t get to be fluent in everyone’s approval.

“The crumb’s a touch tight,” she said, and she touched the dough with the tip of one finger like a pianist checking the instrument. “The draught did you no favours.”

“I felt it,” I said, which was both a joke and a confession.

“The flavour’s considered,” Elsie said. “Rye can be a brag. Here it’s a story.”

“You like a metaphor,” Crispin said, as if accusing me of something he couldn’t decide to forgive, and then he added, “but it’s not heavy. It eats better than it sounds.” He put a small piece of the milestone roll in his mouth and made a face that suggested surprise. “Quince and caraway,” he said. “I would not have said yes on paper. I’m saying yes now.”

They moved on and I stood very straight and told my hands not to touch my apron. The twins had made biscuits like a map you could break apart, and it was charming and the kind of clever that needs a frame, and the frame here was the word “Northern” and we all felt it. Hester’s roly-poly looked like a station buffet and tasted like a walk after rain. She had used suet without apology and Jam like a route. The beekeeper’s ring had generous sweetness and a tilt towards summer that the judges did not entirely encourage in a room that was thinking about grit. We lined up again and the voices from above became the hush a room makes when it wants to be fair.

Shivani took the microphone not because she enjoyed the power but because somebody has to say the thing that makes several hearts fall and several hearts skip. She thanked the sponsors and the venue and the volunteers who had wiped things with a thoroughness that would have been comic in any other year. She told the audience that clapping had to be done without standing up, which produced a wave of half-laughter that made me love my town. She looked at Elsie, who looked at Mei-Lin, who looked at Crispin, who looked at his moustache because some men require props for courage. It was as if a chorus of birds had to agree on a tune and then decide who would sing the first line.

“We have a winner,” Elsie said, and the way she said it made it sound like the winner would be a cake rather than a person, which felt right. “For a bake that told a story without turning it into homework, that tasted like layers and read like a route we recognised, and that was, not to put too fine a point on it, technically sound.”

I glanced down the line because there is a part of me that has always looked away at the crucial moment, like a lover who doesn’t want to see a flinch. Jas stood with her hands clasped, eyes on the table edge, as if she had been taught long ago not to ask a room for anything. When they said her name she looked up with the specific disbelief of someone who is used to carrying practical things and being thanked only by the absence of complaint. Saj slapped Luke’s shoulder and whooped and Hester clapped the way experienced women clap when the point has been made. I clapped too, loud enough to make my palms sting because there are moments when bitterness would be simpler and you choose not to be simple.

They gave two commendations, which felt like a word designed to be pinned to a blazer. One for Hester, whose jam-to-dough ratio had made Elsie nod as if she had heard a well-argued point. One for me, for flavours that had chosen each other with deliberation, and for a concept that had not tripped me, even though it could have. I nodded and accepted the paper circle with its ribbon as if I were collecting a certificate in Year Six for citizenship, and I surprised myself by not wanting to make a joke. Alfie came over and hugged me with more shoulder than chest, which is the way men hug when they want to be kind and curated, and he told me he’d had a banana in his bag like a lucky rabbit’s foot and left it there out of respect, and I told him that showed character.

When we were released back into the warm muddle of people and noise, when the cameras blinked their last blink and the ovens went dull and the list of ingredients on my bench looked like the remains of a party, I let myself sit on the edge of my station for the first time all day. Rani arrived with the sign and waved it like a flag at a funeral because she understands tone, and then she propped it against my bench and kissed my forehead with a theatricality she reserves for moments she wants me to remember later with a smile rather than with an ache. Mo approached slower, as if walking through a new room and checking the floorboards. She put her hands on either side of my face and did not speak for a minute that lasted long enough to fit in several past versions of me, and then she said, “You told them a thing and they heard you,” and I realised that this, more than a ribbon, was the prize I had needed.

We wrapped the braid carefully and Mo took half for the neighbour who would later knock twice and pretend not to be moved and then be moved. I slid the parkin from its paper and cut squares as if I were cutting a deck for a trick, and I slipped two into a napkin for Elsie, who said, only partially under her breath, that people forget a cake that makes them cry on the day and remember the one that improves when they are alone. Jas and I swapped slices like children with stickers, and her pastry held a whisper of cardamom that made me want to sit and listen. Ayo told me he had never met a camera that behaved so well and I told him it was because it had spent the day near dough. Shivani pressed a hand to my arm in that way people in charge do when they have to move on to the next thing and want you to know you were part of this one. Rani took the whisk from my bag and used it as a sceptre and Mo took it back with an expression that invented a new subsection of disapproval.

Later, when the room had been given back to its metal and its floor, when we had folded our aprons into ourselves and slipped out into the air that had been waiting, we stood a moment on the wet steps and watched the city breathe. The canals showed their backs in the late light and the fairy lights on the footbridge at home had been persuaded to behave. I carried my bag and my commendation and a roll of tape that had somehow made itself mine. Mo linked her arm through mine and said we would drop bread at Mr. Halley’s and then go to hers and eat something that did not require judgement, and I said she had just described chips. Rani walked backwards, delivering her debrief as if I were an athlete who needed to hear he had legs, and she told me I had kept my brioches and my metaphors in line and therefore belonged to my own day. I promised to bring the sign back to her flat because even the most ambitious cardboard needs a rest.

On the tram home a boy in a red hoodie wore his medal on the outside of his coat and held his mouth in that way that means you cannot speak because your throat has decided to be brave. A woman read a paperback with cracked plastic on its cover and breathed through a laugh and then checked herself as if laughter had to be rationed. A man asked another man what stop this was and the other man said he didn’t know because some days you can ride the whole line and still be between. I leaned my head against the window and felt the train make its sibilant way and thought that I had done the oddest and most ordinary thing. I had made the morning into something someone else could taste. I had looked at a map and then made it with my hands. I had said yes and found that, inside it, there were other yeses, small and mean and generous and necessary.

At Mo’s, we unwrapped the remainder of the braid and ate it with butter we said we didn’t need. Marmalade was affronted by the smell of other places on my coat and then forgave me when I produced a piece of parkin as if I were paying tribute to a small, furred tax collector. We put the ribbon on the mantel, where it made the other objects look as if they had been waiting for company. Mo told me the names of every person she had spoken to in the audience and what they did and what they thought and who they had loved, because she has a way of extracting biography with the gentleness of a dentist. She told me that when I stood with my head tipped to listen to the judges she had seen my father, and I told her a kettle had done the same to me, and we agreed that there are places where the past rises like steam and the trick is not to back away from it.

In bed that night, the storm having taken its grievance to the next town, I lay on my side and thought about the way the knife had gone through the braid and the way Mei-Lin had pinched the crumb and the way my hands had found their proof without a gadget. The book called to me, a polite cough from the corner, and I wrote with the duvet over my legs and the cat in her doughnut shape at my feet. My protagonist stood at the lemon tree and did not touch it this time. He turned away and walked along a canal that did not belong to his childhood and watched the water carry a sheen like tea across its back. He passed a boy wearing a medal. He saw a woman holding a whisk as if it were a torch. He kept going, and I kept him company, and the night went with us until it became morning again and the sun put its hand through a torn cloud and found the exact place where flour had been.

The morning after smelled of last night’s sugar and something like relief. My phone had become a small festival, banners unfurling in the form of notifications from friends of friends and strangers with usernames that offered me cake in exchange for stories. Rani had sent a link with a timestamp to the moment she had lifted the sign and then put it down again and then lifted it with amended bravado, and her message was the sort of exultant that always finds the single hinge in me that needs oil. Mo had written, Make sure you eat a decent breakfast and not just glory, and then, half an hour later, What is glory when you slice it. Marmalade sat on the back of the sofa as if she were supervising a staff of invisible interns and blinked at me with patience that was not patience at all but the knowledge that I would come to my senses and open a tin.

I made tea with the solemnity of a newly sworn juror and watched the stream again until the parts of my body that had been braced eased down into something like ordinary. The braid looked like a thing I had done on purpose and not a thing that had let me do it, which felt like a generous trick of the camera. The comments were primarily people arguing about whether a cake could be moody and someone asking where they could buy quince in Barnsley, and one person saying that you could tell I was a northerner by the way I held my bowl as if it were something that might leave if not loved. I laughed and then felt the warm flush of being seen in a way you do not want to admit you enjoyed.

By ten the doorbell had received three polite misuses. Mr. Halley knocked once, pretended to carry on down the road, knocked again and then stepped back as if worried I would think him needy. He wore a scarf the colour of pennies and smelled faintly of something medicinal that had been fashionable when buses were orange. I handed him half the braid wrapped in paper like a letter and he held it against his chest in a gesture that made my throat do the nonsense thing. He didn’t talk about the programme or the commendation ribbon that Mo had propped near her clock, because he is the kind of man who thinks fuss should be kept for emergencies and births, but he put his hand on my shoulder with a weight that said he had watched the whole thing and had done some muttering on my behalf.

“I watched a bit,” he said, which in Mr. Halley’s lexicon is a confession of obsession. “You were neat. That’s half of it. Neat keeps parts from flying off when you change speed.”

“There was a draught,” I said, because it felt right to blame weather in front of a man who had coaxed vehicles through every version of it.

“There’s always a draught,” he said. “Buildings breathe because people forget to. You did your little bowl trick. Smart. Bridget used to say the aqueduct at Barton taught her that water holds its shape if you ask nicely and build the walls. You can’t stop the wind. You can build your edges.”

He nodded towards the painting he had given me and I followed the line of his finger to the pale wash where the artist had left the page clean. The white there had a kind of courage. He told me a story about a driver who had memorised the way the wind came off the river at particular bends and had learned to ride it rather than correct it, and he ended, as he often did, with a joke so understated it felt like a proverb. When he left, I stood for a moment with the door shut and held the quiet like a parcel.

Shivani’s email slipped into my inbox with the modesty of a librarian closing a window. She thanked us for the day and for not swearing and for being the kind of people who could be told a rule and obey it without being told twice. Then, at the end, there was a paragraph that was both an invitation and a dare. Would I consider writing a small piece for the next issue of Hearth & Home, about the experience of making a route out of flour. The column would sit in a section that used to be called From the Hearth and had been renamed The Long Table by someone in marketing who had not wanted to look the word hearth in the face. It would be part recipe, part reflection, with a photograph if I could persuade a friend to take one in which I did not look like I was apologising for my jug. They could pay me, not extravagantly, but in a way that meant I could buy saffron without bargaining with my conscience.

I did not say yes immediately, because I am a man who sometimes likes to pretend that deliberation is integrity. I read the email twice and then did the thing I always do when the day arrives with an extra coat and I’m not sure how to carry it; I went to the library. The air in there had a civic rectangularity that calmed me. The woman at the desk wore a cardigan that could have solved a small disagreement just by draping it over the participants, and the WHISPER PLEASE sign had been handwritten by someone who loved their own hand. Rani was already at a table, a polka-dot scarf looped twice around her neck like punctuation. She had two coffees and a packet of biscuits that had been on offer in a way that made them taste like victory.

“Before you say anything, yes,” she said, when I slid into the chair and put my bag down as if it contained a very small, very loud animal. “Yes to whatever. Yes to writing it. Yes to pretending you ate only one mince pie yesterday. Yes to getting a decent author photograph where you are not holding a whisk like an apology.”

“They want a recipe with it,” I said, trying to sound hapless and failing. “Half story, half method.”

“Your whole life is half story, half method. You were literally born to do this. You came out with a list and a metaphor and a small complaint about the lighting.” She leaned in, doing the Rani thing where she made the ridiculous feel like plain sense. “Write about your dad. Not in a tragic violin way. In a rope-and-knot way. Write about the seam and the locks and you standing there thinking you’re in charge and the canal laughing behind your back.”

“I can’t write my dad into every good thing,” I said, even as I knew I would. “He’ll get tired.”

“He’ll cope,” she said. “Men who put mugs out in the morning can take a little literary wear-and-tear.”

We worked quietly, as far as Rani works quietly, which is to say she hummed and wrote aggressively and every so often looked up and said, out of nowhere, “You could call it A Narrow Cut,” and then wrote the words down on her own paper and boxed them twice. I wrote the first lines of the column with my fingers sticky from biscuit crumbs and found that the tone, which had worried me, arrived on its own feet. It wasn’t the voice of my narrator, who was currently sulking in a lemon grove and refusing to turn towards his own plot, and it wasn’t the voice I used when I tried to be authoritative, which always sounded like I’d been given a megaphone by accident. It was the voice I used when I told Mo a story of a small thing becoming large, and when I told Marmalade that the tin would open, and when I told the dough to wait for me. It was relief to find a register that did not ask me to choose between sincerity and wit, because lately everything had felt like a test I had not prepared for.

At noon a school party invaded, a flock of small coats and bigger questions, and the librarian materialised a courage the size of a bus and persuaded them to enjoy quiet as an activity. One of them broke from the group like a comet and came to our table and looked at my notebook and asked, without preamble, “Do you like cake?” I said yes because I am a citizen, and he told me that his uncle had once hidden a ring inside a fairy cake, and the woman had nearly swallowed it and then said maybe that was a sign. I said that putting jewellery in food was a gamble and his eyes lit with the knowledge that he had discovered a new way to annoy an adult. As they left Rani whispered, “You’re doing a workshop on Thursday,” and by the time I had said “am I” she was texting someone a confirmation and adding, Teacher discount if we bring our own flour.

I took the long way home, past the theatre where Claire had convinced a city councillor that an open day counted as outreach even if there was a bar, past the barber with the window plants that looked perpetually surprised to be alive, past the butcher with his new habit of proffering paprika with a seriousness that implied penicillin. When I crossed the footbridge a man was untangling the fairy lights and swearing with the delicacy of a person who had been brought up near clergy. He glanced at me and said, “You’re the bread,” in a way that made me want to point behind me to a man carrying six baguettes and pretend I had been mistaken for someone else. Instead I said, “I had a bread,” which is not grammar but is accurate enough for a towpath. He asked if my mother was the woman who had cried beautifully, and I said yes, and he said he would be asking her to stand for the council and I said he wouldn’t be disappointed in her principles.

At home, the flat had done that thing home does when you’ve been seen by other people’s eyes; it had become truer in order to reassure me. Marmalade demanded reparations for my absence and then forgave me in exchange for a spoon rinsed under hot water as if I had invented the concept of rivers. I stood at the sink and typed a polite yes to Shivani, added a line about liking deadlines that assumed the shape of a lie, and asked when she’d need it. She wrote back with the velocity of someone who knew how to make a day move: end of the week, two photographs, keep it under a thousand words because nobody wants to scroll forever while holding a cup of tea.

Mo arrived without knocking because I had given her that permission years ago and would not take it back even though she abused it beautifully.
