She carried a tote bag with a hedgehog printed on it that insisted we were in this together, and in it were three apples, a newspaper folded into a kind of swan, and my old scarf that I hadn’t seen since last winter. She put the apples in the bowl and the scarf around my neck and sat down as if the chair had been expecting a sermon. She had watched the stream twice more and had notes, which is the way her pride makes itself useful. She told me my left hand had done a small wobble after Crispin had said the word heavy, and she had written in the margin of her mind, Do not take it in. She told me that Jas had handled her pastry as if it were a breath and had therefore deserved to win, and she told me that the man in the third row with the velvet collar had sneezed silently and she had admired him for that.

“Shivani wants a column,” I said, and Mo smiled in a way that made the kitchen warmer.

“Of course she does,” she said, and then, “Don’t be clever in the first paragraph. Be clean. Put your father in when people are already with you. Make them taste the quince before you tell them why you use it. Don’t talk about roots unless you’re going to talk about boots. People like the sound, but they prefer the heel.”

“You’ve been writing behind my back,” I said, and she shrugged in the direction of the window.

“You put fancy words in your pocket and forget to check them when you do the washing. I fish them out and make soup.” She pulled a notebook from her bag and I caught a glimpse of a page on which she had written, in her crabby open palm, Marmalade should have a say, and below it, Not cute. Wise. I put my hand over my face and she laughed and tapped my knee twice.

The workshop on Thursday was in a classroom with walls that had been painted with slogans by people who had never been shouted at by a slogan. Rani introduced me as a writer and then as a baker and then as a person who could make an egg do what it was told and a metaphor behave, and thirty children looked at me in the way children look at adults who claim to be good at anything. We made buns and called them cobs and then had a friendly argument about the correct word. Flour flicked through the air like an argument between angels. A boy with a serious fringe told me that bees die if they sting you and wasps don’t, which is why wasps are confident, and I considered that this explained many human men I had met. A girl drew a diagram of her route to school on the back of the recipe and coloured the paving stones according to whether they were lucky, and when I asked her how she knew a lucky paving stone when she saw one she said it made her shoe nicer. I read them the part of my book where the man thinks he’s made of winter and half of them rolled their eyes and the other half asked if winter had a colour, and I left the room with flour in my hair and the sense that my yes had purchased me something I couldn’t list on a bank statement.

At the end of the day, washing mixing bowls in the tiny sink of a classroom that had once been a cupboard, I received a message from Alfie with a photograph of his bees looking like small, irritable gods. He had watched the stream again and wanted to give me a jar of the honey he used when he wasn’t performing for men with moustaches. We arranged to meet at the market on Saturday and he added, unbidden, that he had an aunt in Urmston who made parkin that scared him and that he would bring it if I promised to be kind. I told him I would be afraid of it on his behalf and he sent back a row of laughing faces and then a picture of a single bee with the caption, She is a nightmare and I adore her, which made me hope the women in his life were well defended.

On Friday I went to Bury with Mo because she said she hadn’t walked the market in rain for a while and her body had that itch it gets when it needs to be among stalls. We moved through the hall with our shoulders squared and our hands respectful. The fishmonger flirted with Mo in the way men flirt with women they would like as captains, and the spice merchant nodded at me like a co-conspirator and slipped an extra pinch of saffron into my packet with the gravity of a man who has done something irregular. I bought caraway by the fistful because I had given too much of it away in the last week when people asked me what the flavour was and I wanted them to have it in their hands, and Mo bought a small tin shaped like a bus for a child she did not yet know because she is always preparing for visitors. At a stall selling second-hand books I found a slim volume of Lancashire dialect that had been annotated in pencil by someone both pedantic and tender, and on the train back I made Mo listen to me say, “Happen” and “Nowt” as if I had discovered them and she had been using them uncredited for sixty years.

I wrote the column on Saturday morning and sent it on Saturday afternoon because if I had kept it until Sunday it would have become an enemy. I kept it under the word count because I wanted to be the sort of person who could keep their own flour under control. I wrote about the draught and my father’s ladder made of string and the way quince keeps its shape if you coax it, and I did not write about the moment in the room when I had felt my fingers forget themselves because that was for me. Shivani wrote back before tea to say that it had made Elsie put the kettle on and that Mei-Lin had asked if I would please not encourage the entire north of England to pipe quince into bread because she did not have enough counter space for a revolution. The photographer would come on Tuesday and would insist I stand near a window and pretend not to be posed, and could I please iron something even if my mother had ideas about the corruption of irons.

Saturday evening Rani arrived with a rolled-up poster tube and the kind of cake that can only happen when someone has bought more lemons than is reasonable. She unrolled the tube and the sign fell out and made a little thump on my rug, the letters cracking at the edges in a way I found endearing. We ate cake with spoons because we could not find a knife that did not smell faintly of garlic and we talked about the library’s chair situation. There are never enough chairs, she said, and people are always pretending to be okay with three people to a stool. She had been told that the council might fund four more if we could demonstrate usage and she had an idea she wanted me to hate. A bake sale, but not cute. A bake sale in which each item came with three lines from a story and you had to assemble a page by buying three buns. I told her this was a pyramid scheme in sensible shoes and she accused me of being afraid of fun. We scheduled it for the end of the month and she made me promise to invent something for people who didn’t eat butter, which she pronounced with comic sorrow like a priest intoning a necessary sacrifice.

Jas came on Sunday afternoon with a box tied with butcher’s string and cheeks that suggested she had been both praised and scolded by the week. We had exchanged numbers in the kind way people exchange numbers when they have stood under the same light and want to keep that permission alive. She carried herself like someone who had spent years in rooms learning how to hold her tools and her face, and in my kitchen she relaxed two degrees as if the particular clutter told her who I was. She gave me a tart like a folded letter and I made coffee so carefully you’d think it had a camera on it and we sat on opposite sides of the table like a pair of detectives comparing notes.

“I liked your seam,” she said, in a tone that might have sounded arch if anyone else had used it. “It was a risk. You made it behave.”

“I did a little pinch,” I said. “When the draught got ideas.”

“We all have a draught,” she said. “Mine is men in hats.” She told me she had gone home after the final and baked biscuits that had ingredients and anger, and then she had taken the anger out and left the ingredients and had sent the biscuits to her neighbour who watered her herbs when she forgot to water her own life. She asked me if I had ever laminated pastry and I told her no because I like my sanity, and she laughed without sound and described the tiny courage it takes to leave butter where it is, and how the layers will teach you if you let them. We traded half-recipes as if we were smugglers and promised to meet again and not talk about moustaches or men with clipboards for a whole hour.

The week folded itself into a routine that felt almost like a ritual. Morning with tea and Marmalade and a paragraph of my own, then dough, then words that belonged to someone else, then a walk by the water to apologize to my back for the kneading, then returning emails with the briskness of a clerk who likes his stamp. People wrote to tell me their fathers had put mugs out in the morning, and people wrote to argue about desiccated coconut, and people asked me for the quince recipe and then wrote again to tell me they had used apples because quince hadn’t turned up in the shop and could I promise that the result still counted. I said yes because I am not the kind of man who tells a woman from Romiley her cake doesn’t count. The photographer came and made me stand in the doorway and laugh with my mouth closed and then he took fifty pictures of my hands as if they had done the flour all by themselves. He told me his girlfriend had learned to make banana bread during the first lockdown and then unlearned it during the second, and that sometimes her standing at the oven waiting for something to rise had been the only proof he needed that days existed.

Mo decided that her contribution to the bake sale would be a tray of something that could stop a door if necessary. She rifled through her copy of Bero with a nostalgia so sharp I could have leaned on it and got a splinter. In the end she chose tiffin because it sits there looking unassuming and then makes you glad in a way you didn’t prepare for, and because it allowed her to say the word digestive without blushing. We made it late at night in our socks, crushing biscuits with the ends of rolling pins and feeling like vandals, and when the chocolate set we cut neat squares and tried not to eat more than three in the name of quality control.

On Thursday the town discovered a hole in its pavement near the co-op and this gave everyone something to talk about that was not hard news. Men gathered around it with the solemnity of midwives, hands on hips, heads tipped to consider the hole’s personality. A woman in a high-vis vest poked it with a rod as if she were interrogating it kindly. The hole had the arrogance of a young starlet. I watched for ten minutes and then tore myself away and went to the canal where the man with the fairy lights had tamed them and was sitting on the railing like a boy. He told me his mother used to work in the offices at the Glassworks when it was a place for making things that sang and that he had a photograph somewhere of her in a dress that believed in itself. I told him my mother had received a whisk from herself and he said that was exactly the sort of woman he’d be willing to follow into a bureaucracy.

The evening before the bake sale the group met at the café in the library with a purposeful abundance of Tupperware. Benji had made something vegan that smelled like a new kind of science and tasted like a triumph, and Claire had produced small pies that might have been illegal in more than one country for being both generous and unobvious. Richard had created a tray bake cut into pieces named for lines that only trains and hymn writers remember, and each had a little label written in a script so careful it made me feel like I hadn’t loved my own writing enough. Rani moved among us with a clipboard and a borrowed authority and told us that if we made the schoolchildren pay more than a pound for a bun she would put us in her notebook under My Little Tyrants.

At the sale itself the room filled with the hum of people behaving better than they needed to. Children stuck three strips of story to a page and then traded them like football cards and shouted when they found a sentence that matched their friend’s. An old man asked me for a piece of parkin and then told me, as if I had been planning to disagree, that parkin is not for the day, it is for the week, and I agreed and wrapped it and told him to put it in a tin under his stairs. A woman bought two buns and then asked me to sign the paper they were on as if my name would improve the crumb, and when I looked up she was already crying, which is a hazard in a town where emotion is often stored up accidentally and then spilled in front of a man selling his wares. We made enough money for six chairs because Claire had made eyes at a councillor and Richard had sold his railway squares as history and Rani had put out a jar that said NO PRESSURE and the jar had worked like a spell.

Around nine, home with only the corners of the day left, I took out the bowl with the predictable weight and sifted flour into it with the satisfaction that comes from knowing what happens next. Through the wall Mr. Halley sang a full song without stopping and I leaned my head against the cabinet and smiled because the rhythm was the one he used when he sanded a bannister or told a story about the nineteen eighty-six winter. My phone buzzed and I dried my hands, leaving a print like a fossil on the towel. Shivani had sent the proof of the column with a note that said the copy editor had put a comma in a place that did not deserve it, and did I mind if they kept my uncapitalised north because it felt like a choice. I said yes because I liked the way she had asked, and then she sent me the photograph that would go with the piece and I said, unexpectedly and out loud, “All right,” because the man in the doorway did not look apologetic; he looked like someone who would put flour in his hair on purpose.

In bed, the cat finding the hollow at the back of my knees with a precision that would have impressed a cartographer, I took up my notebook and wrote a page that belonged to a man by a lemon tree and a tram line at once. He took the lemon and put it in his pocket for later and walked to the water and watched a boy on a scooter and a woman carry a whisk like a baton and an old man claim a hole in the ground as if it were a story. He kept moving because movement had become the magic, and over him, I let the sentence I do not yet know how to make elegant stand in its ordinary clothes. Yes, I wrote, and yes again, and yes in the small letters that mean I am not being grand, I am only agreeing to be here with my hands.

I woke at four to the sound of rain being rude and lay there with the catalogue of the week on a little carousel, and then I got up and padded to the kitchen because sometimes lying still feels like a kind of piracy. The dough had done its slow thing and when I pressed my finger into it the dent filled in like forgiveness. I knocked it back and it sighed and I thought, briefly and without embarrassment, of my father’s hands. I braided for nobody, and the cat watched me with the sort of disdain that is a compliment if you squint, and the flat filled with the smell of staying. When I cut into the loaf it clicked in that way that tells you the air did not have its way with you, and I ate a slice standing up and thought that some mornings you don’t need rhetoric, you need butter. Outside, the fairy lights on the bridge shone the way they always meant to, not as an announcement but as a proof, and I stood at the window, and I let the day arrive without telling it what it owed me.

The column went live on a Wednesday that had the decency to be grey in a way that made screens feel like fires rather than traps. Shivani sent the link at eight with the brisk little bracket of an emoji that suggested she had already put out two small editorial blazes before breakfast and was ready to put out mine if I panicked. I read it once and then again and then did the ridiculous thing of pretending I was a stranger who had stumbled upon it and needed persuading that quince belonged in bread. It looked like me without the jitters, the photograph catching a moment in which I appeared to know what to do with my hands, a trick of light and posture that any mother would claim as genetic. People found it. They sent messages that were stories disguised as congratulations, paragraphs about the way their grandad crushed cardamom with a hammer and how their aunt smuggled saffron home in a Bible because she trusted God and border guards equally. Someone sent a picture of a loaf with a seam so generous it might have been a motorway, and I wrote back suggesting the B-road approach, which felt like the sort of sentence you only get to write after you have said a large yes in public. Mo read it on her phone with her glasses low and then on her laptop with her glasses high and then printed it and put it under a magnet on the fridge that has been shaped like a tomato for as long as I’ve known what a fridge is, as if paper required the comfort of fruit.

She rang after nine as if she had waited five honourable minutes to call and could not have waited six without exploding into advice. She said three women in the post office had told her they felt seen by the bit about draughts, and one had admitted to using a hairdryer on her dough when the kitchen lost its nerve, and Mo had updated the woman’s opinion of herself just by saying, “I’d do the same,” in a tone that gave the act a cape. “We should go and look at some actual citrus,” she said, “if you’re determined to make your poor fictional man stand under a lemon tree for the rest of our days. We could go to that garden, the big new one with pathways sensible enough for me to complain about anyway. We’ll agree with ourselves about the smell and then you’ll stop writing about it like it’s a ghost who borrowed a bar of soap.”

“I think you mean the one near Worsley,” I said. “RHS. They have a glasshouse the size of a confidence trick.”

“Exactly,” she said. “Bring your notebook. Bring me a scarf. I’ll bring the thermos. We can have a sit and pretend the world is Mediterranean until the sky tells us not to be silly.”

We went in coats that had taken a position on hoods. The bus to the garden moved through Salford with the sort of patience that thinks it might be contagious, and Mo narrated the route with details you don’t get from an app. She pointed at a terrace and said a woman there had once had a canary that sang along to the radio and then refused to sing when the DJ changed jobs; she indicated a corner shop and declared it the best place for funeral lilies because the man had learned gentleness with his hands from a mother who took in sewing. At the entrance she bossed the map as if a path might try to give her the slip, and then, when we found the glasshouse, she let her sensible stride slow as if heat taught behaviour.

Inside it was a separate hour. The air held the kind of sweetness that made your shoulders loosen and your past step aside. Leaves had the gloss that suggests money and good habits. The lemon trees, which I had expected to behave like caricatures of themselves, stood with their small green fists unclenching, their fruit the colour of warnings dressed up as favours. A volunteer in a fleece with the garden’s crest explained very gently to a man in a waterproof that this was not the kind of place you took cuttings, and the man in the waterproof looked as if he had been accused of theft and then forgiven for it on the same breath. I stood with my notebook open and did the thing Rani teased me for, which is to look a scent in the face and ask it questions. The lemon wasn’t furniture polish, though that memory elbowed its way into the room with its jaunty deceptive shine; it was pith and oil, bitterness and promise, the sort of sting that tells you a wound is clean.

“Your father would have hated this,” Mo said, not unkindly. “He didn’t like a plant under glass. He said it made them complacent. But he’d have liked the piping. Look at those hoses, tidy as soldiers. He’d have run his hand along that line and found the place it squeaked.”

“He always found the bit that squeaked,” I said, and because the ghost of furniture polish had invited the workshop in, I saw him at his bench in the old house, the one before we had central heating and after we had stopped pretending we could fix everything ourselves. He would temper varnish like a man bringing a child round from a tantrum, put a glove on and sand as if smoothing a word. He would stand without putting weight on one hip as if he didn’t trust his own balance, and he would tie a length of cord into a bowline while talking about Mondays as if the knot and the day were the same kind of problem.

We sat on a bench and watched a child point at oranges with the seriousness of a scholar. Mo poured tea into the thermos lids and passed me a biscuit she had put in for the sake of the ritual even though she refused to admit that tea tastes wrong without something that crunches. “You could put your man in here,” she said. “He could stand under the lemon and realise he has been waiting for a different tree all along. Or he could end up working here because you’ve given him too much weather and not enough occupation.”

“You make him sound unemployed and easily led,” I said.

“Well,” she said, “he lives in your head. I’m only reporting conditions.”

On the way out my phone did its small tap. There was an email from a person called Caro whose surname had an abundance of consonants that made me think of law firms and expensive moisturiser. She had read the column “with enormous pleasure” and had then “popped over” to my website, which was generous given that my website was essentially a friendly apology with some pictures of bread. She loved the “intersection of narrative and kitchen,” a phrase that made me see a zebra crossing over a chopping board, and wondered whether I had ever considered “a book that explores routes in this way, a memoir with recipes, a map of the north through bakes and the stories that carried them.” There was a calendly link, a word I mistrusted, and three suggested times to chat that week, one of which did not require me to either get up at five or pretend to be a man who used the word brunch like a verb.

I showed Mo the email and she took my phone with the sort of reverence she reserves for photographs of babies and new buildings. “Oh,” she said, and then “oh,” again, and then, quietly, as if the lemon trees might be listening for gossip, “Don’t let them make you into something you can never stop being without disappointing them. But also, don’t be daft. Say yes and see.”

“I can’t be a person who writes only about bread,” I said, aware I was speaking about both pride and fear.

“You aren’t a person who writes only about anything,” she said. “You write about hands. You write about waiting. You write about the way people look at one another when they’re not sure what to say. If she wants to let you do that and buy you some flour along the way, then we will call that a win. And I will order five copies and make Auntie Kath rearrange her mantel.”

We booked a conversation for Friday at eleven, which felt like a time that would allow me to be both articulate and suitably northern. On Thursday Jas messaged to ask if I wanted to come by the patisserie at dawn and see lamination performed by someone whose pastry did not sulk. Dawn and I are not, as a rule, intimate, but I said yes because sometimes your hands need to be humbled and sometimes you need to admire competence up close. I set the alarm for a time that felt like an insult and woke half an hour earlier with the knowledge that Marmalade would take my wakefulness as a personal triumph. She supervised my dressing from the bed, ears pricked, tail scrolling as if she were writing an email of complaint in cursive.

Jas’s place at six in the morning was a chapel that had cracked its knuckles. The steel surfaces had the gleam of a surgery and the bins were lined like a row of school children with their shirts tucked in. She placed a slab of butter on the dough with the generosity of a host and then pressed the whole thing with a rolling pin the length of an oar. “The trick,” she said, “is to accept that most of the action is waiting. You need to tell the butter where it’s going to school and then let it have holidays. Fold, chill, fold, chill. The mistake is thinking you can persuade it with force. The second mistake is pretending the room is not part of the recipe.”

She pushed and turned and breathed through her nose with the steadiness of a swimmer who trusts her tide. I tried, and my butter told me I was an amateur using my kindness like a blunt instrument. I rolled too hard, then too soft, then apologised to the bench out loud and Jas laughed and said, “There’s a kind of swearing you can do without swearing,” and I took that as permission to mutter into the dough as if it had personally betrayed me. She made a thousand layers look like something a patient would request for convalescence. We talked in the in-betweens with the shorthand of people who don’t need to set the scene. She told me about her grandmother’s kitchen and the way the men were expected to leave the room after they had eaten because women required space to speak and knead both, and I told her about a boys’ school cookery class in which the teacher had confiscated three wooden spoons for pretending to be drumsticks.

“You’ll hate it if you get put in a box,” she said, folding neatly. “People like putting us in boxes because it makes them feel like they’ve tidied. They think lamination is women’s work until it gets a television slot. They think your flavours are domestic until someone with a moustache tells them they’re history. Do the thing you can stand behind if the camera goes away. That’s all.”

When I left she pressed a paper bag into my hand that turned out to contain two croissants that had survived being alive by learning to bear their own weight. I carried them home like a courier and Mo appeared at my door the way people appear when scent calls them down a corridor. We ate in silence for the first five bites because there are rules and then because Jas had achieved the kind of balance that made speech feel like a left turn with no indicator. “Hers,” Mo said, with an authority that would have allowed her to sit on a jury for pastry. “You can tell. She’s got that thin thing going on that isn’t insubstantial, it’s intent. She’ll do fine.”

Friday arrived in stepped shoes. I sat at the table with my laptop open and my mug at the correct distance and the whisk watching from Mo’s new place for it on the dresser as if prepared to step in. Caro came onto the screen in a rectangle that suggested daylight and money. Her bookshelf was colour-coded in a way that would have given my father thoughts and me a rash, but her face was frank and her smile lacked the sharpness that can make compliments feel like purchases. She asked after the weather in a way that wasn’t filler because she’d eaten rain and she knew it was a meal.

We talked. She didn’t try to sell me myself, which I appreciated. She had read the piece and some of my zines I’d pretended were private, and she had a softness around the eyes when she said the sentence that made my back straighten. “I don’t want to make you choose a lane,” she said. “I want to see if we can draw two parallel lines that don’t collide and tell a story worth walking along. The essays would be essays. They would not be instructions dressed up in anecdote. The recipes would be recipes, not metaphors that burned. You’d be allowed to be funny. You’d be allowed to be sad. We could call it Northern Routes and then refuse to be lazy about what that means.”

I said the things I’d told Mo about not wanting to be trapped in a flour sack. I said the things I had said to myself about not being ready and then had the good sense to hear them back and dislike them. Caro nodded the way you nod at a child who deserves to keep their reasons and also deserves to have someone hold the door open. “Write me a page,” she said. “Write me a letter from the book to itself. Three ideas for chapters. Tell me what you don’t want it to sound like. Tell me where you want it to be on a shelf. Don’t send me a recipe yet. Send me a mood-board in sentences. If we hate it, we’ll say so and spare ourselves a year of pretending. If we like it, we’ll agree to be brave and to have proper lunches when travelling is a thing again.”

After the call I did the washing up as if I were punishing a spoon for existing and then went for a walk down to the canal to let my posture uncurl. The man with the fairy lights sat on the railing peeling an orange with the concentration of a botanist. He had a plastic tub of bulbs at his feet and the resigned joy of someone who has more projects than days. He nodded at me and said, “She’ll have you writing a book with your name on the front and then you’ll have to buy two of those pens that leak ambition,” and I asked him, mildly, whether all towpaths came with clairvoyance. He held up the orange like a lamp and said, “Your mother works fast and so does my cousin,” and I said, “I know,” and we agreed that if you’re going to be discussable you might as well provide snacks.

At the library that evening, the group held an event that had started as a reading and become a small party because Rani had discovered how to put fairy lights round a lectern without tripping the fire alarm. She had called it Flour and Thunder as if daring weather to take offence, and we had a sign-in sheet that asked for names and whether you’d brought a Tupperware for the leftover buns as though there would ever be leftovers. Claire had organised the chairs so they looked like democracy and Benji had made a zine for the night with a cover that showed a bun in a toga. I read the column and three people made the noise people make when they recognise themselves, the cough-laugh that admits to sentiment without surrendering to it. Then I read a page from the novel in which the man with the lemon tree finally looked up and put his hand on the rough bark, and I dared to leave in the sentence that had felt too much when I wrote it—“He forgave the tree for surviving,”—and Rani rolled her eyes in a way that conceded the point and claimed it for the South Asian auntie’s collective archive.

After, a woman with hair like good grammar approached with the posture of someone who has decided not to make a fuss and is about to do exactly that. She had brought a photograph of her father standing by the Ship Canal in a coat that would have deflected bullets, and she wanted me to have the picture in a way that was not transactional. “He taught me that you shouldn’t be afraid of salt,” she said. “No, that’s not right. He taught me that you shouldn’t be afraid to be savoury.” I took the photograph and promised to think about words, and later that night I propped it beside the whisk and the painting because my mantel had trouble saying no to other people’s lives.

When I got home there was a shoebox on the mat with my name written by a hand that had learned early to make itself obvious. Inside were three notebooks with covers so battered they had developed personality. I knew before I opened them that they were his, and I knew which his without being told. Mo had written a note that said finally, as if the notebooks had been playing an elaborate game of cache-cache in her house for a decade and she had grown bored. The first page contained an inventory of rope knots and a drawing of a boy’s hand that was not mine and that was mine, and a list in pencil that had been pressed so hard I could read the word indent through the page. Lark’s head, bowline, clove hitch, sheet bend. Under the list he had written, “Practise with a purpose,” and then below that, in a different pen, the words, “Don’t let him learn bad habits.” I sat at the table and copied the names into my own notebook and felt something twist and untwist in my chest with a logic my head had no jurisdiction over.

On Saturday Alfie met me at the market with a jar of honey that was the colour of a lie told by an affectionate child. He wore a jumper that had been knitted by someone who loved him enough to count rows, and he waved the jar like a trophy in a competition where the prize was winter. He had brought his aunt’s parkin wrapped in greaseproof with a label that read, “Do not perform on the day,” and he made me promise to leave it alone until at least Tuesday, which I converted to Monday with a small internal footnote I hoped his bee ancestors would forgive. We walked past stalls that seemed to be selling the same five sorts of hope, and he told me how being stung had stopped hurting when he learned to expect the sting, and then he corrected himself and said it never stops hurting, you only stop performing surprise for other people. He had watched the stream twice and liked the way my face had decided not to be witty when the judges spoke. He had decided to paint his hives ridiculous colours in spring and had stuck the paint charts under his magnets in a way that made choice an argument worth having with the kettle.

On Sunday, between the second sleep that counts and the responsibility that puts socks on, I wrote the one-page letter Caro had asked for. I did not proofread it to within an inch of its life because I suspected she could smell fear at that distance. I wrote about how you can tell when a town has learned to carry water and not spill it; about public benches; about ways people talk to one another at the counter when a scone is the excuse; about the old woman who sat with a drizzle cake and read the death notices with curiosity rather than panic; about pepper in gingerbread as a sign of both restraint and revolt. I wrote the three chapters as notes to myself: The Seam, The Draft, The Hands. I wrote the line I did not want it to sound like: I don't want a book that confuses sugar with kindness. I wrote where I wanted it to sit: next to the books people kept by the back door because those were the ones that told them how to get home.

The reply came at the sort of speed that made me feel seen without being hunted. Caro had a note on everything and the sort of enthusiasm that distinguished itself from flattery by bothering with a comma. She thought The Draft could be both literal and not, and that The Seam might be the place to put a father on purpose and not as an accident of weather. She told me to keep writing, to not try to be delightful on every page because delight is better as a surprise than a house style, and I sat at the table and allowed myself the small, private phrase, “We are doing this,” which, when said in an empty room, sounds like prayer.

In the weeks that followed, the town did that thing towns do when you’ve announced something without intending to announce it—it made space and then filled it with opinion. The barber asked if I would include a recipe for the biscuits he pretended not to like and then confessed he liked them a lot when feeling fragile. The woman at the baker’s four doors down told me that if I thought I could write about Eccles cake without being shouted at I should remember I had legs and the ability to run. Mr. Halley held his hat in his hand on a day without sun and asked me if I intended to put anything in about how men forget to eat unless reminded, and I told him the first chapter of any sensible book is called Feed the Men and Nobody Dies, and he laughed and told me I would make enemies in the right places.

One afternoon I went with the fairy lights man to hang a new string under a bridge that was tired of being a passage and wanted to be an occasion. We climb awkwardly, those of us in our thirties who learned to be careful by falling once in front of a woman we liked. He tied knots that were more confident than mine and I felt my father lean over my shoulder and tell me, kindly, to stop second-guessing. On the underside of the bridge, teenagers had written their names with thick pen in a script that managed to be both defiant and correct, and one of them had drawn a heart in which two initials had been crossed out and replaced, and I wanted to stand there and applaud an honest edit. We finished with hands that smelled like electricity and plastic and sat on the edge with our boots over the water and watched a moorhen behave courageously. “Legacy is daft,” he said. “Reputation’s the thing. That’s just how your neighbours talk about you when you’re not there. That you were helpful is enough.” I put that sentence in the book without changing a word and felt, afterwards, that I had not stolen but been lent.

Rani, who refused to let any of us develop delusions of grandeur without paperwork, set us a test in the group. She brought in a bag of objects—an onion, a bolt, a child’s mitten, a playing card bent at the corner—and told us to write the first paragraph of a chapter about each without using its name. We groaned and did it and then found, of course, that the bolt had a story about who it had held together, and the mitten belonged to a child who taught his father to invent warmth, and the card had never won a hand because it had never tried to be anything but itself. She put her feet up on a chair and declared us useful citizens, and then she produced a diary and bullied us gently into writing down dates for readings in towns with names that sounded like places a person would go on purpose and not by accident: Todmorden, Hebden Bridge, Glossop. We all protested travel with comic melodrama and then admitted we would share petrol and return with stories about men in pubs who argued about jam.

On a Tuesday that had no business being as blue as it was, I went to see my mother without warning and found her at the table with three envelopes open and a fourth held gingerly as if it were powdered and might go up in a puff. She had been adding up her bills, which is a phrase that does not sound like the task it is. She looked up and composed her face into the expression she uses when I tell her I’m fine and she decides to pretend I am. I made tea because love is a hot liquid in this house. We talked about rigs in the Ship Canal that my father had admired and the way the council had finally decided to fix the pavement hole with a seriousness that translated into three cones and a sign. She told me she had received a letter from the GP surgery reminding her she was due a something with numbers and she would go because she believes in both medicine and the power of a nurse who remembers your name. I pretended not to clock the slight stiffness in her left shoulder when she took the mug because watching your parent age is like watching weather set in over a landscape you have walked since you were a child—you notice the dips, you tell yourself the water always pooled there, you inventory umbrellas. She caught me looking and said, “I am sturdy enough to complain,” which in her lexicon is a certificate of fitness.

That night, back at the table, my hands did their now-habitual choreography—measure, mix, wait—and I opened the Father Notebooks again as if they would cease to be legible if I ignored them. On a page near the end, between a list of sandpaper grades and a drawing of a bracket he had meant to buy, he had written one sentence that might have been for me or for a version of himself he still believed he could persuade. “Remember to do things you like in front of the boy.” I stared at it until the words stopped being words and turned back into marks made by a hand that could not have imagined me at a table reading, a cat deciding whether to sleep or supervise, a loaf beginning its slow proof like a patient heartbeat. I turned it into a rule I could live with. I wrote it on the first page of the notebook I’d bought in Bury. I told it to Rani, who underlined it twice and declared it the most useful manifesto she had heard from a man all year.

In the middle of the week, in the hour that often gets away because it doesn’t try hard to belong to anyone, I sat, finally, in a café that had nothing to do with the library and tried to write the chapter called The Draft. The draught itself obliged by creeping under the door, touching my ankles and reminding me that romance is mostly about practicalities. I wrote about sleeve cuffs and door edges and a baker’s wrist, about the way tempers shift when the air misbehaves. I wrote about the patch of cold in the Glassworks that had threatened to make a fool of me, and about the metal bowl I turned into a small climate and something like an ark. I wrote about Mrs. Boylan from two doors down when I was nine, who kept a towel under the front door and called the wind her lodger, and how she would say, “He pays in stories,” and then tell you a lie about her first kiss being stolen by a man standing in a draught. The sentences behaved until they didn’t, and then I gave them a biscuit and they behaved again, and every time my hand reached for the honey I made it take the pen instead.

I ended the week with half of something that looked like a book if you squinted and with a sourdough starter that had been neglected in favour of more theatrical yeasted things and had therefore invented its own personality. Marmalade sat beside it on the counter and regarded the bubbles with the suspicion of a bureaucrat inspecting an expense claim. I fed it with a little flourish as if it deserved ceremony for simply being alive. The window threw the cold kind of light across the floor and my boots made the click that tells you a season has changed its shoes. I sent the pages to Caro with a sheepish line about the commas and the impulse to please that needed managing, and she wrote back with a voice note instead of an email, as if to remind me that sometimes a human mouth is a better editor than red ink. She liked it and liked me liking it, which is a separate joy. She said keep going, which is sometimes the only sentence you need.

Late, when the town had gone to bed with its radios on low and its appliances plugged in as a statement of faith, I sat at the desk and wrote the second scene in which my lemon man looks at a canal and decides to it rather than from it. The cat made her doughnut at my feet and the dough in the bowl proved itself capable of patience and the radiator clanked with that endearing something that sounds like someone apologising far away. I ended the paragraph where he puts his hand on the metal rail and says, out loud and undramatically, “All right,” and I leaned back and let myself grin. On the table the photograph of the man in the bulletproof coat watched, and on the mantel the ribbon failed to pretend it was not pleased with itself, and in the corner the whisk gleamed in a way that made it look like an instrument of state. I sent Rani a message that said simply “page” and she replied with twelve clapping hands and a picture of a banana with a red cross through it because she knows how to puncture and inflate in the same gesture.

In bed, the room finally conceding to the dark, I lay and thought about the morning and the next morning and the mornings after that. I thought about all the little yeses the week had required and the big ones I had managed to give with a straight back. I thought about the way the fairy lights had found their discipline under the bridge and about Jas’s patience folding butter that behaved better than most of the men I’d met in publishing. The moon did that indefinite trick with the cloud and the curtain and the cupboard and I felt overly poetic about it for a second and then allowed myself to be. I slept like a man who had found a way to be hungry and content in the same day, and when I woke I had a sentence in my mouth and a kitchen that smelled like a plan.

The morning bent itself into the sort of grey that asks for permission rather than forgiveness. The kettle sang without drama, the radio murmured about roadworks as if narrating a long relationship, and Marmalade performed the delicate act of ignoring me while positioning herself exactly where my elbows would want to be. On the screen, Caro’s name appeared above a subject line that made my stomach practice a small somersault and then pretend it had not. The words were careful and generous at once. She’d shared the pages with two editors she trusted and both had written back with sentences that used the word “shape” as if it were both noun and verb; one of them had once said no to a book about a fox that went on to be a phenomenon, so she liked her yeses considered. Would I be able to meet in town on Thursday? She’d be at the hotel near Piccadilly with a lobby that had ideas about itself, and we could talk timelines, sympathy, commas, and money, in that order or the reverse depending on my superstition. I read it twice with my mouth full of toast and then again after I swallowed like a man checking for a bone, and then I rang Mo because the act of good news is not complete in our family until it has been placed like a dish between us.

“Thursday,” she said, as if summoning a day by the scruff. “I’ll come to the station. I’ll behave. I’ll sit at a distance and pretend I’m not your mother, and if she passes me at any point I’ll smile like a woman who knows things and is dignified about it. Take a notebook and a pen that doesn’t announce itself. Wear the shirt that makes you look like you iron, because you don’t and mustn’t be caught out. If they ask you to write quickly, tell them you can write steadily. If they ask you to be charming, be honest instead.”

At the hotel the carpet had the kind of pattern that is both expensive and tired of being trodden on by people who have opinions about service. The lobby’s plants wore their own lighting, and the coffee was priced as if coffee were an event and not a drink. Caro met me with a smile that contained no edges and a coat that had learned to hang off a shoulder without looking like a performance. We took a table near a window that had mistaken rain for art, and she unfolded the afternoon with a competence that made the thought of the book stop pretending it was a ghost. We spoke about chapters as if they were rooms we could furnish and then leave without apologising, about the way the word north sits down differently in different mouths, about recipes that don’t act like bait. She had a notebook full of names that sounded like both cabins and battleships, and when she spoke about copy editors she did so with what could only be called tenderness. Money arrived last, as promised, and she put the numbers down on paper as if making a small altar. It would not make me a baron; it would make rent feel less theatrical. She asked if I needed time to think and I told her I need time by default, but I did not want to spend it all on doubt. She laughed, properly, and said, “Good,” in a tone I trusted.

I had not intended to orchestrate a collision, but Mo believes in fate if fate can be reached by a tram. She arrived with the weather on her coat and a smile at Caro that would have felled a weaker agent. Their handshake contained a negotiation and an agreement to continue to like one another in a crisis. Caro called her Mo within two sentences and got away with it because names behave differently around women who have boiled milk for a living. They discussed lemons with unnecessary seriousness and timelines with the cheer of people who know how to ride a late bus. When Caro asked about titles, Mo said, with the plainness she uses to shut down melodrama, “Call it whatever you want so long as you remember people take books into kitchens, not the other way round.” Caro wrote that down and underlined it and looked at me over the top of her notebook with the expression of someone delighted to be corrected.

On the way home, carrying a loaf from a bakery that overpriced its crusts and underpromised on its crumbs, Mo caught the toe of her boot on the doormat that insists we wipe our paws and stumbled in that slow-motion way that suits the elderly and the overcautious. I reached without thinking and she steadied without drama, and we both performed the ritual of pretending this was not a preview of later. In the kitchen she rolled her left shoulder in a circle that implied honesty more than pain and said, “It gets stiff when the weather makes a poem of itself. I’ll mention it when I go in for the numbers thing. Don’t say ‘frozen shoulder’ or I’ll put you in the bin.” I said nothing about bins or ice or the way her tea mug rattled, and instead sat and let her tell me about a woman she’d met on the bus who had dyed her hair blue in defiance of an invisible council of critics and had been praised by teenagers as if she’d invented the sky.

At the library the table looked like a cross between a field hospital and a craft fair. Rani had pinned an agenda to the corkboard with dots that demanded attention, and she wore a scarf that she claimed could double as a banner if revolution broke out in the biography section. I read the beginning of The Draft, and midway through the second paragraph a chair scraped and then obediently returned to its station, and I had the small high of speaking sentences that had been difficult to coax. Benji said it made his wrists cold in a satisfying way. Claire said I needed one more woman who didn’t care about my metaphors. Richard, bless him, described the draft in terms of railway cuttings and incline resistance and then, because he is a friend, asked me if I was going to put commas in places where they would not embarrass us. We ate biscuits with the seriousness of surgeons on their break and planned a trip to Hebden Bridge where the bookshop owner had promised to overorder on optimism and chairs.

When the world is too noisy, I bake things that can afford to fail. I told myself that using the last of the expensive saffron in a midweek experiment would teach me a lesson about humility. Marmalade heard the jar open and launched herself gracefully into the exact space where gravity would be most persuasive if it wanted to win, and for a second the air was full of red filaments that fell as if someone had insulted them. We picked threads from the floor like thieves and I put the rescued shreds into milk and watched it take the colour the way a person takes a compliment only if they believe it. I made a knot I did not intend to keep and ate it hot with honey because I could not think of a reason not to, and my mood, which had tilted towards the edge, found the middle again because sometimes it is as simple as the smell of something that does not require a verdict.

The train to Hebden Bridge did its best to prove that steel has a sense of humour. We sat with our scripts and our Tupperware and a conviction that we would triumph by numbers alone. Out the window the hills behaved like they had been waiting to be noticed. In the carriage a woman knitted the sort of cardigan that made you think of solved problems, a man whispered into a phone as if conspiring with his own life, and a girl read a horror novel with an expression that suggested she would not be taken in by cheap jumps. The bookshop had windows that believed in afternoon light and a floor that had decided to slope long ago. We read to a room of expectant coats and faces arranged into interest, and when I did the paragraph about a draft finding your wrists, a man in a cap said, at normal volume, “Aye,” and then blushed like a child who has been caught out loving. After, a woman told me her mother used to stand with the oven door open and warm the kitchen as if it were a body, and that in her house the word “proof” had nothing to do with documents. I signed three copies of a book I had not yet written as if I were witnessing a marriage that would not take place for years and bought a second-hand paperback with a flyleaf that had loved someone else more than it loved me.

When we were packing the banner back into its indignity, my phone buzzed with the plain text of fear. Mo had rung the surgery because the stiffness had become honest and the nurse had made the sort of face over the line you can hear. It wasn’t urgent, which is a word that can be both cloak and knife; it was a come-in for tests and don’t panic in extremely large letters. I told Rani in three sentences and she became a shape we all rely on, folded the chairs with vengeance, corralled our troupe, pressed money into my hand as if I had forgotten I possessed any, and ordered me to send her a text the second I knew anything even if the result was banal. On the bus to the clinic the air was the kind that tells you to be grateful for windows. I sat with my head against the cold and watched other people carry their catastrophes in plastic folders. The nurse was brisk and kind in a way that made me miss being looked after. Mo did not apologise to her body for being a body; she surrendered an arm, an elbow, a list of symptoms that were trivia-colored and grievances that were new. The tests would take a week, which in the language of worry is a year. We walked home with her insisting muscles were attention-seekers and me pretending to believe her. We made soup that tasted like refusing to give in, and she told me again to say yes to the book without twitching.

Caro sent a draft contract with notes in the margin that sounded like a human being. There were paragraphs about territories that made me feel like a landowner and then immediately like a thief who had nothing to show for his theft but guilt. The advance looked like a thing that could turn an old oven into one that didn’t sulk on the left. I allowed myself the fantasy of paying my mother rent without theatre, of buying Marmalade the kind of food that implies she is royalty and I am staff, of not counting the days between invoices like beads on a string. I wrote a scene in the novel in which my lemon man took his hand away from the tree and felt, to his own irritation, that his palm had learned something by contact. He walked along a canal that was not ours, watched a swan behave as if it owned the list of names in the Civic Registry, and admitted, out loud in a paragraph, that he had absolutely no idea where he was going but preferred moving to standing still.

Jas asked if I wanted to go in on a bulk order of quince because the market stall woman had misjudged the appetite of a town and was now looking at a crate like I look at my novel on the bad days. We met in the market’s late afternoon when everything has become a little too honest. She had a list and a rolled-up tea towel with a stain in the exact shape of an apology. We drank tea that had been brewed in a metal kettle older than Benji’s optimism and watched a man buy a piece of smoked cheese that required its own legend. Jas told me, carefully, about a built life that had not become a marriage and the odd relief of a disaster that is administrative rather than apocalyptic. I told her about the notebooks in my father’s handwriting and her face did the thing it does when someone brings her a pastry she respects. We did not make a promise to talk about any of it again, which felt like a promise worth trusting.

We decided that saying yes requires a ceremony, however small. Rani arrived with a sign that had been amended so many times it had become postmodern, Alfie came with a jar of honey that had learned to taste of the place it had been made, Claire brought a bottle of something bubbly that had not been grown anywhere near here and refused to feel guilty about it, and Mr. Halley knocked twice and then once and presented a story like a dish—how he had taken a corner too fast and learned the names of his own hands. Jas came late with a tin that did not advertise its contents and the expression of someone who has kept something safe. We set the good plates on the table because if you can’t get the good plates out to celebrate a contract you may as well sell them. I said, into the kitchen air, that I had signed a piece of paper and did not feel like an imposter because everyone was also eating. We raised mugs and glasses and a whisk because Mo insisted the whisk had earned the right to attend any ceremony. I made a toast that included the word “bread” only once and used the word “enough” more than once, because there are times when you must pick a noun you can live inside.

Later, when their coats had gathered themselves and taken their owners home, I stood at the sink and watched the fat from the stew behave like patterns I could not read and put my hands into the hot water as if I could acquire competence by immersion. The flat held the shape of company for a little while, the chairs inclined towards one another as if they had been listening, the air warm with the intelligence of recent laughter. On the mantel the ribbon had rotated in the draught and was showing its less photogenic side, the painting of the aqueduct watched with patience, the whisk gleamed in a way that implied it had ambitions beyond egg whites. I dried my hands and wrote a page before bed, because I have discovered that if I do not feed the book before sleep it comes to the edge of the bed and asks for a glass of water in a child’s voice.

A week has a way of wandering if you don’t pin it, and this one required new pins. The results at the surgery described a problem with words that sounded like a legal document: degeneration, inflammation, an old injury that had taken its time to introduce itself properly. It was not a catastrophe. It was an adjustment. Physiotherapy. Exercises in a corridor that had decided to smell of disinfectant and resilience. A nurse who said, “You’ll be cross,” as if pronouncing a benediction. Mo consented to being looked after as if she were humouring us, resolved to take rest as if rest were a suspect neighbour, and stared a leaflet into submission. We got home and I moved the heavy pan to a lower cupboard without being told to, and she said, “Don’t start behaving like I’m a legend whose relics must be venerated,” and then smiled because she knows how to leave a gentleness on a phrase that might otherwise cause trouble.

Caro sent back my notes with her notes on my notes and a question about whether I would mind if the cover didn’t show a loaf but a map. I told her I wanted the sort of cover that would look at home on a kitchen table and not embarrassed in a train carriage, and she wrote back a single sentence that made me tear up for no grand reason: “We will make the kind of book that sits by the back door.” Contracts were printed on paper that made me feel complicit in deforestation and responsibility. I signed without flourishing because my father’s hand had taught me that flourishes hide trouble. We spoke about a launch that would not pretend to be a coronation. Claire offered the theatre on a night when the roof did not leak, Rani promised a lectern that would not tempt me to slam it, Benji proposed zines tucked under chairs like stowaways, and Richard said he would liaise with the man who had opinions about microphones and pronounce him a friend for the evening.

The lemon man had been sulking in a corner of my head and now he came out and admitted he had stopped being afraid of being too obvious. He stood in a kitchen that was not mine with a kettle that had learned to obey a hand it did not recognise. He sliced a lemon with a knife that was not very sharp and decided he would write a letter to a person he had not forgiven and tell them they had not broken him, they had bent him into a shape that turned out to be useful in a storm. He walked the path by the water and said hello to a moorhen and did not take it personally when the moorhen ignored him. I wrote him into a tram, and for the first time he did not consider jumping off before his stop in the name of drama.

At six one morning, the hour that belongs to milkmen and women who train for marathons and men who cannot resist the message tone in their pocket, I woke to Marmalade standing on my chest with the unambiguous expression that translates as, If you think about the book before you think about my breakfast I will move out. The scoop made its small moons, the tin surrendered, and the house reclaimed its equilibrium. I opened the laptop and the email was there, tidy as a sandwich. Caro had spoken to production. If we wanted to catch a season that made sense, I would need to deliver the first complete draft in six months. My mother would say that time was elastic and could be taught manners; I thought of the lemon man, of Jas folding butter, of Mr. Halley’s admonition to sit my hands, and I said the sentence out loud that turns air into a contract. I can do that. Then, because words are cheap until you feed them, I wrote four pages before breakfast and did not tell anyone until lunch.

On Saturday we tried being tourists in our own lives. The markets were full without being crowded, the sky had ventured a pale blue, and a busker with a borrowed voice sang a song that had made a generation slow dance. Alfie presented me with a small jar of pollen as if I were a priest and he had a confession, and I bought it and didn’t understand it and took it home anyway because sometimes the point is not comprehension but participation. Jas had a tray of pastries that did not pretend to be polite, and the woman from the stall with the handsome cheese told me that my column had made her husband argue with a spoon and she had enjoyed watching him lose. Mr. Halley pointed at a poster on the side of the bus shelter advertising a council meeting and suggested, with the gravity of a man who had fought a battle with a pot plant and won, that Mo ought to attend and then accidentally run it.

We ended the day with onion gravy and chips from a place that had been given more awards than it had wall space. In Mo’s front room the ribbon had been relocated to a spot near the clock where it could observe time without being its servant, the photograph of the man by the canal had acquired company in the form of a snapshot of a baby who had no idea she had been born into a family that would discuss her elbows for a week, and Marmalade had discovered that if she stared at the fish tank in the dentist’s window for long enough she could see herself and make peace with the idea that another cat existed. We ate with our elbows on the table because dignity is for breakfast, and Mo told me about a woman her age who had gone to the physio and come back with an exercise band and a belief in her glutes, and I said the word glutes in a way that made us both laugh because some words are only funny when said in your mother’s kitchen.

That night, tired in the good way and hollowed out by tasks rather than by fear, I put the bowl on the counter with its dependable weight and fed the starter that had forgiven me for my flirtations with commercial yeast. The radio murmured a match report as if reading a bedtime story to a nation, the upstairs neighbour dropped a shoe like a period at the end of a sentence that had gone on too long, and outside the fairy lights on the bridge came on with the discretion of a curtain opening at the exact moment it remembers it is paid to open. I wrote a paragraph about a girl who chooses her paving stones and a woman who hides saffron in a jar that used to belong to her grandmother’s buttons, and then I turned the laptop off and let the room become simple again. On the table the contract sat under a book to encourage its manners, on the mantel the whisk shone like an instrument of state, on my phone Rani had sent a photograph of a chair with the caption SIX and three exclamation marks, and in my hands, flour did what it has always done for me when the world asks me to stand up straight. I kneaded until the dough stopped keeping score and I could feel my own shape in my palms, and when I finally slept, it was with the knowledge that morning would arrive without needing me to instruct it and that I would be ready, tea in hand, to say yes in the small ways that keep the large ones honest.

The next week tested my newfound confidence as if it were a pair of shoes. The first event was a small radio spot with a presenter who had the voice of a man who had found his own throat late and was still grateful. The studio smelled of old carpet and fresh coffee, which is to say it smelled like professionalism. He introduced me as if I had already written three books and one of them contained an answer to something important, and I remembered Rani’s advice to decline grandeur politely without throwing it back like a child. We spoke about parkin as if it were a form of voting, about the weather as if it had a grievance, about the act of handing someone a bun and believing it could help. In the middle of a sentence about quince I looked through the glass and saw Mo in the waiting area, knees together in the way she sits when pretending to be demure, and she mouthed the word “behave” and then immediately laughed at herself. After, the producer handed me a biscuit in the manner of a man who had decided I was likely to forget to eat if unprompted, and the presenter whispered, as if revealing a library secret, that he had cried at the line about the draught and had then thought about his grandfather and checked himself in the toilet mirror until he looked like a man who could go back to his desk and read emails.

School visits have a way of turning a person into a collection of useful anecdotes, and I learned how to tell mine like a tale rather than a résumé. The year tens wanted to know if you could earn good money writing about bread and whether I had ever been on proper telly and if I could put their band in the acknowledgements. In a cooking classroom with knives tethered like nervous pets, we stirred batter and they leaned on the counter and I watched them pretend not to hope that someone would tell them they were good at something. A boy asked if I’d ever been to London without my mother and I said yes and he looked impressed as if I’d just said I’d slept in a tent in the rain. A girl said she liked when I wrote about men being a bit useless and still deserving cake, and I told her that was my favourite subject and she rolled her eyes as if I were obvious and grand and correct.

Between days that belonged to other people I made the private, ordinary ones work. I went early to the physio with Mo and took notes as if muscles had a curriculum. The physio had forearms that could persuade a brick to behave and a kindness that arrived like a cushion. “It will be boring,” she said. “It will be glorious in its boring. Do it anyway.” We bought a ridiculous ball to roll against a wall, a band that looked like something a child had made and turned out to be a device for truth, and stickers like we were bribing a six-year-old and decided we were. We came home and did our first set with the solemnity of a launch, and Mo put a sticker on the calendar and said, “That’s me defying entropy,” and then she ate a biscuit to balance the universe.

The book’s skeleton began to stand up in my notebook, a wonky figure given life by paragraphs that had been playing dead for months. The Seam took my father and returned him without embalming him, The Draft took my own hands and asked them questions, The Hands took people I have watched measure flour and translated them into a language that let someone in Bolton read about a woman in Bradford and nod at the same moment. Caro sent me emails that acted like lights down a corridor, and when I sent her a page that I knew was half a page she did not scold, she asked me what belonged next, which is why I chose her to stand next to my work with a clip and a pen.

Jas came round one afternoon with a bag that clinked because she had bought jars at a charity shop that had previously held optimism and now wanted stewed fruit. We sterilised like champions, the kitchen steamed, Marmalade sulked because no one had consulted her, and the quinces reluctantly gave up their shapes and turned into something a spoon could make sense of. We talked about nothing for a while and then about everything, which is the right order. She stayed for tea and another, and when she left I found a postcard on the table from a patisserie in Vienna, a photograph of a cake that had decided to be a sculpture, and on the back she had written, “Butter says yes to heat if you keep your nerve,” which struck me as the sort of sentence you can use for almost any problem if you are brave or foolish.

At night, when the town performed its quiet and the canal did its black mirror trick and the trams whispered the news of the city, I sat with the page and sometimes produced a neat paragraph and sometimes produced a cross face. On those nights I paced the kitchen and said the sort of myths to myself that suit men alone in rooms—about work, about fathers, about weather—and then I peeled them off like wallpaper and tried again. I learned to end the day with something small done: a paragraph that did not embarrass me, a dough folded for the morning, a biscuit put aside for a friend, a message sent to a person who had given me a story and needed to know it had become something. When sleep came it did not always arrive with its arms open; when it did, I was grateful enough to forgive it for being late.

The morning Mo rang to say she had found the old recipe for a kind of bread her mother had made and could not name, I left the house with my keys still in my hand as if I were fleeing a crime scene. The paper was soft with being held and the handwriting had been done with a nib that misbehaved. The first line read, “Enough flour for purpose,” the sort of instruction that would give modern bakers an existential crisis. We made it together to see what purpose meant, me reading the ghosts of measurements, her stopping me when my wrist lied, the oven doing its old uneven song. It came out squat and proud and smelling like comfort, and we ate a slice with butter that tried to escape and failed and she said, “That’s her,” and then, under her breath, “Hello,” in a tone that made my eyes behave badly. I put the recipe in a plastic sleeve because I am not above acts of clerical devotion, and I wrote the story down before it started to turn into legend in my hands.

Months have a way of stepping up behind you and clearing their throat, and this one was no different. The book had become more than a rumour; the novel had stopped sulking at corners and started turning them. Mo’s shoulder, worked into ordinary, had added a repertoire of noises to our living room soundtrack, and we could tell the difference between a good click and a rude one. The fairy lights under the bridge had been replaced twice and re-tied with a competence that suggests love. The man at the butcher had decided paprika was not a human right after all but a kindness he would not be held hostage by. Mr. Halley had a new hat that made him look like a man you ought to take seriously when he said the winter of eighty-six was a proper winter. Marmalade learned to open a cupboard and then, having mastered it, decided she would rather be admired than use her powers.

One night, at the end of a day that had required me to be seven people—son, writer, neighbour, baker, man in a shop choosing a lemon, man on a bus watching a toddler negotiate stairs, citizen—Rani sent a photograph of the theatre lit up for an event that was not ours. “Soon,” she wrote, which can be a threat or a promise. I held the phone and felt the panic that pretends to be a friend when you have something to lose, and then I took a pan out of the cupboard because sometimes the only thing to do with nerves is to cook them down. I made onion gravy with patience and wine and the sort of attention I reserve for sentences I hate and people I love, and halfway through I remembered I had promised to write five hundred words before bed and I wrote six hundred and stopped before a paragraph ended so I could begin clean the next day. Then I stood at the window, the city stroking its own back with light, the canal holding steady as if to say I’ve got you, and thought how strange and lucky it is to be a person who can turn a day into a line and a line into a loaf and give both away without feeling emptied.

When I finally lay down, the cat took her place with the entitlement of the only creature in the house sure of her job. The whisk on the mantel tilted a fraction in the breeze we pretend not to have. Somewhere a tram sighed as if satisfied with a shift completed without incident. My hands, which had learned to recognise the proofing bowl in the dark, rested in the space between. Morning would come and bring with it the list and the kettle and the pages I had not yet offended, and perhaps a man with a moustache, perhaps a child with a question, perhaps a bread that wanted to tell me who I was trying to be. I closed my eyes and told the coming day I would meet it at the door with my shoulders down and my pen ready, and in the last seconds before sleep I thought, without embarrassment, that I might be equal to what I had asked for.
